fields.headline: Scottish Widows admits security breach
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Insurance group Scottish Widows yesterday apologised for a security blunder in which at least two policyholders were wrongly sent other people's confidential banking details, including account numbers and password information.
fields.body:
Insurance group Scottish Widows yesterday apologised for a security blunder in which at least two policyholders were wrongly sent other people's confidential banking details, including account numbers and password information.

The incident, the latest in a string of security lapses involving leading companies, came as the insurer started sending out windfall cheques averaging £5,700 to almost 1m policyholders following its acquisition by Lloyds TSB.

Among those to benefit is Sandra Bruce-Gordon, who decided to put her windfall into an account with Scottish Widows Bank and was "appalled" to receive a letter from the company which included another policyholder's personal and bank security details.

Mrs Bruce-Gordon, of Staines, Middlesex, alerted the other policyholder, who lives in Manchester, and found that she had received Mrs Bruce-Gordon's details.

Scottish Widows apologised for the error, saying that "a mix-up of this magnitude is unacceptable". The incident was an isolated case, but it had initiated a staff training review, it added.

Mrs Bruce-Gordon, who has a Scottish Widows endowment policy, filled in a form to have her windfall paid in to a Scottish Widows Bank VIP Premier Account. She later received a letter from the bank asking for clarification of a detail, and attached was an application form filled in by Jane Ireland, together with a copy of recent transactions on Mrs Ireland's main bank account.

"As the application form had been completed I was able to see all of Mrs Ireland's security details, bank account numbers and personal contact details."

Mrs Bruce-Gordon said thousands of policyholders would have opted to open a Scottish Widows Bank account. "I am sure more than two ended up with other people's information."

In a letter to Mrs Bruce-Gordon, the company apologised and said the mix-up was the result of "human error".

The incident comes three weeks after Barclays Bank was forced to shut its online banking service for some hours after customers found themselves able to access other people's account details.

PowerGen and Woolworth have also fallen foul of internet security problems during recent weeks.

Scottish Widows yesterday began the distribution of £5.8bn of windfall cash to 1.6m policyholders.

webTitle: Big players wait on the Fed

fields.headline: Big players wait on the Fed
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Although there is an almost universal expectation that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and his colleagues will leave US rates on hold this evening, market professionals were taking no chances yesterday.
fields.body:
Although there is an almost universal expectation that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and his colleagues will leave US rates on hold this evening, market professionals were taking no chances yesterday.

In a lacklustre session, values of the leading shares ended little changed as institutional investors headed for the sidelines, refusing to make any big plays until the announcement is made.

Ever since the Fed started to tighten interest rates in the middle of 1999, the meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee have been crucial events for global equity markets. By the close of trade the FTSE 100 was 1.5 points weaker at 6,542.2 - off the day's low of 6,491.4 - as Wall Street started the week in positive territory.

Just over 1bn shares were traded, with market heavyweight Vodafone, down 3.5p at 264.5p, accounting for 212m of that total.

Boots was always among the best blue-chip performers yesterday, lifted by reports that US discount retailer Wal-Mart is considering a £6bn takeover bid.

While analysts thought a bid by Wal-Mart was unlikely, they said the story served as a reminder that, at current levels, Boots is not only cheap but vulnerable to a takeover.

A year ago Boots shares were changing hands at 750p. Last night they closed at 516p after rising 16p.

Sainsbury, which has been mentioned in various quarters as a buyer of Boots, ended the day unchanged at 325p.

Securities house Merrill Lynch has upgraded its long-term recommendation on the stock to "accumulate" from "neutral".

Analyst Sara Carter thinks it is wrong to write off the company. If it gets its act together - and there are signs that under the leadership of Prudential boss Sir Peter Davis this is happening - Carter reckons the shares could hit 390p.

Allied Domecq, up 7.75p to 332.75p, bounced back from Friday's weakness, helped by whispers that the Swedish owners of Absolut vodka favour its bid for the drinks business, Seagram.

Vin & Sprit, which has granted the distribution rights for Absolut to Seagram, is said to be ready to oppose a sale to the Diageo-Pernod Ricard consortium.

Biotech company Celltech was in demand, adding 36p to £14.21, ahead of interim figures next month. According to Lehman Brothers analyst Ian Smith, the company may even report a small profit.

On the down side, Anglo-Norwegian health group Nycomed Amersham fell sharply after CSFB's top-rated biotech team restarted coverage with a "sell" recommendation. CSFB reckons fair value for Nycomed shares is 437p, compared with yester day's closing price of 583p, down 19p.

CSFB claims the market is wrongly valuing Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, in which Nycomed has a 55% stake, as a knowledge company for drug discovery rather than an equipment manufacturer.

After Friday's near-20% rise on the back of Nortel Networks bid speculation, Bookham Technology came back down to earth with a bump. The shares ended 160p lower at £30.80 as investors moved to lock in gains.

Among the second-liners Fibernet, the long-distance telecoms specialist, gained 150p to £17.00 as Deutsche Bank repeated its "strong-buy" rating and eye-catching £27 target price.

Deutsche believes the share price only reflects the fair value of Fibernet's British operation and completely ignores the potential of its expansion into Europe .

In the small cap universe, aside from the usual demand for stocks tipped in the weekend press, eyebrows were raised by the late surge in wallcoverings and carpets group Walker Greenbank. Its shares ended 7.25p better at 39p, on turnover of 3.5m.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival theatre review:  Cabin Pressure

fields.headline: Cabin Pressure
fields.standfirst:
Royal Lyceum Theatre *

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Royal Lyceum Theatre *
fields.body:
Cabin Pressure, from the New York company Siti, will feel radical only to those who have missed the last 20 years of theatre. Its central premise only feels edgy in the cosy, sleepy vale that is the international festival. It is a play about seeing a play, an audience-themed show in front of - you might have guessed it - an audience. Wow.

The cast play scenes from various dramas. We see backstage, offstage, and the backs of props. Too much in love with the cleverness of its lame, tame idea, the play bends the notion of audience this way and that (there is even a kind of post-production group therapy in which the characters grapple with the indescribability of great theatre). But it never breaks down the barriers between the company on stage and the punters in seats. They tell us how weird and sometimes beautiful it is to sit and watch, but also describe the ennui that mediocre work can produce: "I was very embarrassed most of the time." I couldn't have put it better.

Ends tonight. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

fields.headline: Few ideas down under
fields.standfirst:
The Antipodes
Shakespeare's Globe, London ***
fields.trailText:
The Antipodes
Shakespeare's Globe, London ***
fields.body:
Peregrine is a young man who reads too much. His head is full of blue elephants, woolly chickens and dog-headed men, put there by Sir John Mandeville, the bogus knight whose medieval travelogue made such a mark on the English imagination. Peregrine is so desperate to follow in his hero's footsteps that he won't even consummate his marriage. After three years, his wife is ready to climb the walls.

Peregrine's father, Joyless, calls in the 17th-century equivalent of a psychiatrist, who resolves to cure the madness by faking a trip to the other side of the world with the help of a band of actors. And so begins a long play-within-a-play that immerses Peregrine in an "anti-London" where cats must be protected from mice, prostitutes are pillars of society, and sick men give healthcare tips to doctors. Meanwhile, Doctor Hughball attempts another cure: that of Joyless, who is terrified his own young wife will cuckold him.

The Antipodes, or The World Upside Down, first saw the light in 1638, but has not been staged professionally for 350 years. Its author was Richard Brome, Ben Jonson's former servant, who produced a string of comedies such as A Joviall Crew and The Sparagus Garden. But while Shakespeare's Globe describes this play as a "neglected masterpiece", that's only half true. The Antipodes is an enjoyable mingling of broad humour and social critique, but it milks its few ideas for all they're worth, and demands faultless acting and direction if it is to rise above the mass.

Instead, what we get is a partial success. The play-within-a-play is hilarious, thanks to the actors-playing-actors, who seem to be having the time of their lives. Geoffrey Beevers as the neat, self-satisfied Hughball, Penny Layden as Joyless's wife, Diana, and Mark Lockyer as Byplay, the ever-resourceful chief actor, all give first-rate performances. But director Gerald Freedman appears to have forgotten that, in a comedy, there's no point reconciling estranged couples unless the audience want to see them together.

There's little he could do with the pairing of fresh and devoted Diana and dry old Joyless (blame Brome's text); but Freedman and his cast badly misjudge the younger couple. Peregrine (Harry Gostelow) and his wife, Martha (Karen Tomlin), should be affecting as well as ridiculous; instead, he is so insipid and she so brainless that you couldn't give a damn whether they ever get it on.

Until September 22. Box office: 020-7401 9919.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival theatre review: The Tempest

fields.headline: The Tempest
fields.standfirst:
The Quad ****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The Quad ****
fields.body:
The Tempest is the favoured Shakespeare play at Edinburgh this year - there are six productions on the fringe. But A and BC Theatre Company's outdoor production is certainly out of the ordinary.

For a start, the audience is asked to sit in the middle, perched on small oil drums, while the drama takes place all around. The actors emerge, circling the audience and shaking drums full of stones. It is a simple touch, but the storm is instantly raised. This is Shakespeare at its most direct and immediate, full of infectious fun.

There are some wonderful touches: not just one actor but the entire cast play Ariel, their voices filling the air and echoing around the courtyard so that the island does indeed seem to become a magical place full of spirits.

This production makes you feel like a kid again. As the play draws to its magical climax, we all lean forward upon our seats to drink in every magical moment like moths being drawn towards the light.

Till Sunday. Box office: 0131-530 3557.

fields.headline: EasyJet shuns consumers
fields.standfirst:
Shares will be offered only to institutions

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stelios Haji-Ioannou, owner of the budget airline EasyJet and self-styled consumer champion, has decided not to allow small investors to buy shares in his company.
fields.body:
Stelios Haji-Ioannou, owner of the budget airline EasyJet and self-styled consumer champion, has decided not to allow small investors to buy shares in his company.

Mr Haji-Ioannou, who plans to float about 25% of EasyJet in the next couple of months, will offer shares only to institutional investors and not to the retail sector.

The decision was taken because of fears of repeating the lastminute.com fiasco, in which thousands of small investors tried to buy shares in the online travel agency.

Those applicants who did get shares were disappointed by the small allocations they received and then by the sliding share price.

EasyJet executives believe too many people would be interested in investing in the company if shares were offered to the retail sector, leading to many investors holding relatively small stakes.

Amir Eilon, a non-executive director of EasyJet who is advising on the float, said: "We can't afford to run the risk of a lastminute.com experience."

An open initial public offering would have meant that anyone could have invested in EasyJet, necessitating a ballot system for allocating shares.

Sources point out that a £150m open flotation would see only £20m worth of stock available to retail investors, thus limiting the number of shareholders, given the minimum £1,000 stake, to 20,000.

"You have to give people a reasonable allocation and the problem with that is the number of people that you satisfy is far too small," said Mr Eilon, a former senior investment banker.

The company has used the figure of 5.5m people flying EasyJet this year as an indicator of potential interest in investment.

"Even if you look at passengers as people who have indicated an interest in the company, versus the numbers who haven't, the numbers just don't add up", Mr Eilon said.

"The problem is you can't satisfy enough people, even if you double the percentage [of EasyJet stock] available, so that's why we've decided to go institutional offer only."

However, Mark Dampier, head of research at the stockbroker Hargreaves-Lansdown, said: "It seems very strange that a company that is the peo ple's airline has chosen not to address the people."

Other companies with mass appeal have resorted to corporate "handcuffs" to ensure shareholders hang on to stock. Carphone Warehouse, which floated last month, offered retail investors an optional three-month "lock in" period in the company's recent intial offering, with a promise of a full allocation of stock.

At least 90% of the 11,500 retail investors who applied for Carphone's shares took up the option, with a minimum application of 500 shares at 200p each. Retail investors who did not agree to the restrictions only got 60% of the shares they applied for.

EasyJet is valued at about £600m but began business in 1995 with just £5m of launch capital.

The initial public offer, together with share options which will be made available to employees, will dilute the stake owned by Mr Haji-Ioannou and his family from 100% to just over 71%.

Earlier this month Mr Haji-Ioannou announced he was planning to float his growing chain of 24-hour internet cafes.

The internet business EasyEverything was valued at £100m after venture capital business Apax Partners and Hewlett Packard injected £20m.

The pitch that almost made Luton fashionable

In EasyLand everyone is equal. The orange huts at Luton airport that house EasyJet's operational headquarters bear no visible signs of hierarchy. Receptionists and chairman sit alongside each other in matching orange T-shirts.

At the weekly company barbecues, founder Stelios Haji Ionannou is as likely to be serving the burgers as eating them.

This folk hero for the underdog may have no intention of forgetting his staff - but the passengers who helped turn EasyJet into one of the success stories of the decade will not be allowed to buy shares.

This seems to go against almost everything the 33-year-old has stood for since setting up with a £5m loan from his shipping magnate father in 1995.

Stelios' no-frills airline took advantage of airline deregulation and pitched at cost-conscious customers not travelling on company money.

The service cuts out travel agents and almost 80% of flights are booked on the web. At check-in, passengers quote a reference number, are given a laminated reusable orange boarding card and make a dash for one of the unallocated seats.

EasyJet now flies 28 routes to 18 destinations in Europe on one of the industry's newest fleets. In the next few weeks it will start taking delivery of 15 next generation Boeing 737-700s.

Stelios stood up to SwissAir's attempts to muscle him out of the Geneva to Barcelona route and argued that Go, its budget rival, is unfairly subsidised by BA.

Visitors to EasyJet.com are greeted with a banner screaming: Stop Barclays increasing your airfares by £5 - a reference to the high street bank's desire to increase landing charges at unfashionable Luton airport in which it has a 25% stake.

webTitle: Exchange refuses to delay iX ballot

fields.headline: Exchange refuses to delay iX ballot
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange yesterday refused to bow to pressure to postpone the crucial vote of members on the plan to merge with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange yesterday refused to bow to pressure to postpone the crucial vote of members on the plan to merge with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse.

The exchange's chairman designate, Don Cruickshank, said the ballot of the exchange's shareholders would take place on September 14 as planned.

Exchange members had sought a delay to allow more time for discussion of the complex issues raised by the proposed merger of the London stock exchange and the Deutsche Börse, which would see blue chip trading based in London and hi-tech dealing concentrated in Frankfurt.

Yesterday the merger came under fire from the Centre for the Study of Financial Innovation, an independent City think-tank.

The CSFI report, titled iX: Better Or Just Bigger, said the merged exchange would find it difficult to achieve real gains in efficiency.

It added: "The merger fails to advance the two key requirements for pan-European equity trading: an independent centralised counter-party and a unified settlement system. The most the merger prospectus is able to say is that these are long-term objectives."

However the stock exchange argued that the merger would deliver savings for British brokers and private clients trading in Germany and vice versa, and promised more details next week of how the merged exchange would handle settlement.

The financial services authority and its supervisory counterparts in Germany yesterday issued a joint statement on their plans for regulation of the merged exchange.

The supervisors have set up six working parties to look at different aspects of the merger, and said they planned to establish permanent forums to exchange information.

"The development of iX-international exchanges needs to take full account of requirements of market integrity - in particular the prevention of insider dealing and market abuse - and of market transparency and the protection of investors." The authorities agreed to "undertake coordinated supervisory assessments of common rules, membership standards and disciplinary procedures and other relevant developments of regulatory interest concerning iX group on an ongoing basis".

The statement focused on the broad outline of a post-merger regulatory framework. Detailed proposals will depend on the proposals advanced by the exchanges.

The stock exchange and the Börse welcomed the joint statement, describing it as confirmation that "the supervisory authorities are committed to providing effective regulatory arrangements for the operation of iX international exchanges as they develop".
fields.bodyText: The London stock exchange yesterday refused to bow to pressure to postpone the crucial vote of members on the plan to merge with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse. The exchange's chairman designate, Don Cruickshank, said the ballot of the exchange's shareholders would take place on September 14 as planned. Exchange members had sought a delay to allow more time for discussion of the complex issues raised by the proposed merger of the London stock exchange and the Deutsche Börse, which would see blue chip trading based in London and hi-tech dealing concentrated in Frankfurt. Yesterday the merger came under fire from the Centre for the Study of Financial Innovation, an independent City think-tank. The CSFI report, titled iX: Better Or Just Bigger, said the merged exchange would find it difficult to achieve real gains in efficiency. It added: "The merger fails to advance the two key requirements for pan-European equity trading: an independent centralised counter-party and a unified settlement system. The most the merger prospectus is able to say is that these are long-term objectives." However the stock exchange argued that the merger would deliver savings for British brokers and private clients trading in Germany and vice versa, and promised more details next week of how the merged exchange would handle settlement. The financial services authority and its supervisory counterparts in Germany yesterday issued a joint statement on their plans for regulation of the merged exchange. The supervisors have set up six working parties to look at different aspects of the merger, and said they planned to establish permanent forums to exchange information. "The development of iX-international exchanges needs to take full account of requirements of market integrity - in particular the prevention of insider dealing and market abuse - and of market transparency and the protection of investors." The authorities agreed to "undertake coordinated supervisory assessments of common rules, membership standards and disciplinary procedures and other relevant developments of regulatory interest concerning iX group on an ongoing basis". The statement focused on the broad outline of a post-merger regulatory framework. Detailed proposals will depend on the proposals advanced by the exchanges. The stock exchange and the Börse welcomed the joint statement, describing it as confirmation that "the supervisory authorities are committed to providing effective regulatory arrangements for the operation of iX international exchanges as they develop".

fields.headline: Testing times
fields.trailText: 22 August: My new employer says I did not do well enough in my induction programme and I will now get the sack if I fail external exams. The thing is, my contract said nothing about sitting exams.
fields.body:
The problem

I recently took part in an induction programme for a new company but I, and several others, failed to reach competency in certain areas. My company now says it is compulsory for me to sit an external exam and they have changed my terms and conditions of employment to include this.

Nothing in my original contract said that I would have to sit exams but if I fail they will terminate my contract. Is this legal?

Donald Johnstone

The solution

I am assuming that your company has changed your contract of employment to include the new terms and conditions. I am also assuming that these changes in contractual terms have been without your agreement. If you haven't objected then in due course it could be regarded that you have agreed to the changes.

As you have experienced an imposed change that has involved a significant alteration to your original contract, your employer may well be acting in fundamental breach of contract. This means that if you quit, you could (in theory) make a claim of constructive dismissal. Similarly, if you were fired for failing the exams, you could (again in theory), claim unfair dismissal. I say "in theory" because you will normally need to have been with the company a year before you can try and make a claim for unfair/constructive dismissal. And, even if you did make a claim, you might not win since the tribunal would take into account whether the employer acted reasonably - and requiring you to be up to scratch in some areas might be considered reasonable (although firing at first failure might not).

I advise you to seek legal advice from your union or local ACAS public enquiry point. You might find that the simplest course would be to take (and, hopefully, pass) the exams and have another string to your CV bow.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Edinburgh festival classical review: SCO / Christian Zacharias

fields.headline: SCO/Christian Zacharias
fields.standfirst:
Usher Hall ****
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Usher Hall ****
fields.body:
Christian Zacharias is now deep into his seven-concert cycle of the Mozart piano concertos. Abandoning chronology, he has designed each programme to present three concertos composed at different stages of Mozart's life.

Zacharias turned the relatively unfamiliar and early C major concerto K 246 into a small-scale drama, moving from the opening allegro's ebullient hunting horns to the courtly minuet of the last movement. His approach to the orchestra is an efficient compromise between period-band affectation and the weight of modern instruments. The Scottish Chamber Orchestra obviously relish their special relationship with Zacharias, and are not afraid to follow the lead of his sometimes idiosyncratic phrasing as he directs from the piano.

The thematic fecundity of the E flat major concerto K 449 was richly satisfying. But Zacharias's performance of the great A major concerto was the most fascinating of the concert. His first movement was unusually brisk and forceful, a long way from the veiled eroticism this piece conventionally possesses. Sometimes Zacharias's articulation can be fussy. But in the slow movement and the final Allegro, he found a totally idiomatic spontaneity, matching Mozart's invention with his own creative inspiration.

fields.headline: Graft
fields.standfirst:
Komedia @ Southside ***
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Komedia @ Southside ***
fields.body:
In a festival that seems in danger of disappearing up its own backside as pieces about acting play to audiences made up almost entirely of actors, George Dillon's one-man show about the highs and lows of being an actor should be missable. That it isn't is a tribute to his source material - Steven Berkoff's painfully funny novel - and the fact that it allows Dillon to do what he does best: overact.

Working-class Harry becomes an actor against the odds, but finds that he suffers for his art. Up against Oxbridge prejudice, the indifference of agents and the possibility of 10 weeks playing the hind legs of a donkey, Harry finally gives his last and best performance at Leicester Square tube station. The portrait of the descent from bright-eyed hopeful to desperate depressive rings true. One show that all those Edinburgh hopefuls should see.

Till Sunday. Box office: 0131-667 2212.

webTitle: FSA orders net blackout on share tips

fields.headline: FSA orders net blackout on share tips
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The mounting concern in regulatory circles about the power of the internet to move share prices was underlined yesterday when two financial news websites were told that it is illegal for them to reprint share tips from newspapers.
fields.body:
The mounting concern in regulatory circles about the power of the internet to move share prices was underlined yesterday when two financial news websites were told that it is illegal for them to reprint share tips from newspapers.

The financial services authority has told the companies that they are not permitted to reprint the share tip information because they are not registered financial advisers - even though newspapers do not have to abide by the same rule themselves.

Newspapers and magazines are exempt from the restriction as investment advice is not their primary purpose, an FSA spokeswoman said.

The clampdown comes as the FSA is seeking to clarify its position on a range of internet-driven financial information sources including bulletin boards and chat rooms, which have at times been abused by rogue share promoters. The FSA is expected to outline its feelings in the autumn.

Sharepages.com and Digitallook.com both said yesterday that they had suspended publishing round-ups of weekend newspaper tips at the request of the FSA.

Several other leading financial news websites said that they had not been contacted by the FSA but would fight to keep their tips summaries as they were merely repeating information that was already in the public domain.

"It seems bizarre that we are forbidden from merely repeating information that is already widely circulated, especially since we are not altering, interpreting or commenting on it," said Sharepages' managing director, Marc Pinter-Krainer.

"We have suggested ways that the law could be modified but at present we haven't been able to reach a positive outcome," Mr Pinter-Krainer said.

Digital Look said it would now only publish the name of the stocks tipped and provide a link to the relevant newspaper website.

The FSA was at pains to emphasise that it was not "anti-internet", and said that it was working with the Treasury on ways to update legislation so that it took into account how the internet was changing the way in which people buy shares and find out information about companies.

Rules governing the newspaper exemption were drawn up in 1986 - long before the internet became a mass phenomenon.

"It wouldn't matter if the tips were written on the back of an envelope or on the internet, the law prevents those not registered as financial advisers from making stock recommendations," the FSA spokeswoman said.

"This is all about protecting the consumer. We are looking at ways of making regulation technology neutral."

fields.headline: Sketching with sound
fields.standfirst:
Dirty Three
Manchester University/ Touring ****
fields.trailText:
Dirty Three
Manchester University/ Touring ****
fields.body:
Maybe you can't dance to Australian instrumental group Dirty Three, but you can certainly wail and fling your arms about like frontman Warren Ellis, a madcap violin virtuoso and occasional Bad Seed. Standing for the most part with his back to the audience, Ellis hunched over his electric fiddle like a demented genius, his lank hair falling over his face and threatening to interfere with his bow. At times, he played with such furious strokes that it looked as if he was trying to saw off his other arm, and, when not hacking away, he shouted and spat and synchronised kicks to the slowly marching bass drum.

Though his wild fiddling offset the absence of vocals, Ellis also worked an endearing line in introductions, offering screwball vignettes of the inspiration behind each track. One song, he told us, was about "waking up and finding that you've got a pony-tail on the back of your head".

Seven-minute sound-sketches are the band's thing, and One Thousand Miles captured the wind-in-your-hair exhilaration of driving nowhere in particular. Mick Turner's strong, clean-cut guitar riffs, and Ellis's feverish scraping were pinned together by Jim White's alternately soft-handed and hard-hitting percussion.

Having assured us that Some Summers They Drop Like Flys (sic) from their latest album, Whatever You Love, You Are, was about badly-fitting tracksuit bottoms, Ellis teased out a folk tune somewhere between a serenade and a lament, which might well have charmed the worm from a bottle of tequila. It's this combination of touch and terror that distinguishes the band's sound, for the song reached a climax worthy of an exorcism, with Ellis falling to his knees, happily flagellating his fiddle.

Dirty Three also do lounge-bar melancholy to remind you of the last time you were sucking ice-cubes for drops of JD. With Ellis once again genuflecting, and the stage dark apart from two green spotlights, the encore, Lullaby for Christie, offered doleful strains of violin, accompanied by little flurries of guitar and drums. Sweetly elegiac, it was the perfect way to put their offbeat blues to bed.

At the Union Chapel, London (020-7226 1686), tonight.

fields.headline: The Toes
fields.standfirst: Garage, London ****
fields.trailText: Garage, London ****
fields.body:
The Toes say their influences range from the Rolling Stones to Phil Spector. It's certainly reflected in the five-piece's sound: swaggering, bluesy rock'n'roll mixed with a freakish soul, as exemplified on their debut EP, Lung Oyster Blues. Arguably, such retro-flavoured rawness helped win them their deal with Cornershop's label Meccico Records: early Cornershop were themselves a bundle of punky energy. But, at this show, the Toes prove they also possess great catchy melodies and fantastic assurance.

Wearing oversized shades, nonchalantly smoking and shaking orange maracas, frontman Ritchie is impossible to ignore. They open with a louche, funky instrumental, Captain Nemo, and, from then on, every number builds into a mental wig-out, with Ritchie at the helm, strutting around the tiny stage like a weird hybrid of Jagger and Jarvis Cocker. When he sings about "sippin' lemonade", you feel pretty sure Ritchie favours mouthwash of a more rock'n'roll variety. He is a frontman with plenty of front.

This is an engaging, occasionally shambolic affair: honky-tonk tunes are coaxed from a synth balanced on orange crates, there are smashed up beats and rasping guitar riffs. But if the Toes' performance revels in rock'n'roll cliches, they also boast a commendable lack of self-consciousness and an irresistible sense of enjoyment. Their glammy encore even takes inspiration from the TV show, Gladiators. Doused in sweat and beer and adrenalin, their message rings ear-splittingly loud and clear: excess is best.

fields.headline: Tourette's Diva
fields.standfirst: BAC, London   ***
fields.trailText: BAC, London ***
fields.body:
Many people who attend the Royal Opera House are shocked to see a rucksack in their hallowed auditorium. Heavens knows what they'd make of the foul-mouthed work that is Tourette's Diva.

Composer and librettist Richard Thomas is enamoured of both the image of opera - the extravagant gestures, heightened emotions, ladies with proclivities to suicide - and the playground humour: incessant swearing, provocations and obscene insults. His sometimes surreal, often hilarious work is at its best when the gap between the two is eradicated, and the two mezzo-sopranos stand, arms aloft, eyes aflame, elegantly singing of masturbating with vegetables.

There is a structure, of sorts. Daughter Diva, immaculately sung by Lucy Stevens, is undergoing a nervous breakdown and receiving little sympathy from her mother, sung with equal beauty but less consistent volume by Lore Lixenberg. "How come I've got a penis?" Daughter wonders. "You're kidding no one - it's a banana," Mother replies. Their lengthy catfights amuse and bore in equal measure; far more entertaining are the lewd sketches and one-liners that link these scenes and betray Thomas's past as a stand-up comedian. Mother, lavishing praise on the internet, concludes: "Without it my clit wouldn't have been seen by a school in Nantucket."

This is hardly groundbreaking, although one sketch does veer towards Chris Morris/Blue Jam territory: Mother, poised beneath a disco mirror ball, sings the Corby 5000 Electric Trouser Press Aria, rolling her eyes maniacally while dancer Omar F Okai slinks across the stage in a pair of pin-striped trousers. The scene marks one of the production's problems: there is not enough going on visually. You long for directors Delyth Thomas and Lucy Stevens to take the pastiche all the way and fill the stage with velvet and candles, rather than just paint the room black.

The costumes, at least, are fantastic: Stevens emulates Maria Callas with her long black dress and fringed scarf, while Lixenberg struts the stage with her breasts wrapped in coiled vipers.

Till Thursday, then August 29-September 2. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

webTitle: Proms review: The Book with Seven Seals

fields.headline: Apocalyptic excellence
fields.standfirst:
The Book with Seven Seals
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3 *****
fields.trailText:
The Book with Seven Seals
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3 *****
fields.body:
Franz Schmidt thought his oratorio The Book with Seven Seals his finest achievement, and it is a masterpiece by any standards. Yet chances to hear it in this country are rare. Sunday's magnificent account, conducted by Franz Welser-Möst, was the first at the Proms, and only the second time that a work by Schmidt had been included. Perhaps it's the work's provenance that told against it here: it was premiered in Vienna in 1938, just two months after the Anschluss. Within a year Schmidt was dead, and so did not live to see Europe overtaken by the apocalypse that this setting of the Book of Revelation foreshadows, and the destruction of the tradition that his music embodied.

Though he had lived through two shifts in Austro-German music, the first triggered by Schoenberg and the second by the neoclassicism of Hindemith and Weill, conservative Schmidt remained embedded in 19th-century tradition. The language of The Book with Seven Seals is founded upon the language of Wagner: the swinging, bell-like melodies that begin and end the work could have come straight out of The Mastersingers; the numinous aura that surrounds Christ's words is translated from Parsifal, the narrations of St John himself constitute a tenor role as demanding and expressive as almost anything in The Ring.

Chromaticism does sometimes intrude, but only as a pictorial device in a work full of extraordinary imagery to suggest evil or unease - in the piled-up choral dissonances that conjure a vision of war as the seals are unlocked and the four horsemen of the apocalypse unleashed upon the world, and especially in the slithering organ solos that begin each of the two main parts of the work, which owe a good deal to Reger. But the power Schmidt exerts over this musical world is totally persuasive; he handles the huge forces - six soloists, as well as large choir and orchestra - with massive assurance, and an unfaltering sense of dramatic pacing, mixing narrative, aria and chorus in a way that looks back to Bach's passions.

It's hard to imagine The Book of Seven Seals better presented than it was here. Welser-Möst excels in this music, and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, Singers and Chorus, all of whom were surely coming to the score for the first time, were superb: the huge climax at the end of part one, and the joyous, floating hallelujahs which celebrate the final judgment were, in their different ways, equally memorable. Stig Andersen sang St John, unflaggingly, and Laszlo Polgar was Christ; Christiane Oelze, Cornelia Kallisch, Lothar Odinius and Rudolf Hartman were the other soloists and Timothy Bond wrestled with the RAH organ. The most important Prom of the year so far.

fields.headline: Zinzin
fields.standfirst:
Dynamic Earth ***
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Dynamic Earth ***
fields.body:
Just how far British circus lags behind its European counterparts is demonstrated once again with the arrival of an overseas troupe that seems effortlessly to incorporate character, narrative and even philosophy into its trickery. Zinzin won't be the most spectacular circus you'll ever see, but it is completely charming and in its fearless high-wire walkers, fantastical tumblers and pyrotechnics you get a glimpse of an almost medieval world.

The whole piece is played on a single truck and there are only four performers, wonderfully exotic, mismatched creatures who race about like naughty children. They fly because they dare.

fields.headline: At this price?  Boots
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: There was a rare spring in the shares of downtrodden Boots yesterday, as the market reacted to a Sunday newspaper story that the retailer could be bought by Wal-Mart. The price jumped 16p to 516p, having collapsed from more than £10 over the last 18 months.
fields.body:
There was a rare spring in the shares of downtrodden Boots yesterday, as the market reacted to a Sunday newspaper story that the retailer could be bought by Wal-Mart. The price jumped 16p to 516p, having collapsed from more than £10 over the last 18 months.

The chances of such a takeover are slim - Wal-Mart has built its success in the US on aircraft hanger-sized stores selling everything from lentils to lawnmowers. Boots's neighbourhood outlets offer little obvious appeal.

Paradoxically, it is the threat of competition which has done most to depress Boots's shares in the last year. Wal-Mart recently opened its first UK superstore, with many prices as much as 30% lower than those on the high street.

The US retailer is a prime example of the process by which supermarkets are becoming one-stop shops for all household needs, taking in Boots' traditional territory of toiletries, cosmetics and over-the-counter medicines.

It is hard to see how Boots can persuade shoppers to continue buying toothpaste and toilet rolls without sustaining much lower margins. The company has responded with initiatives offering chiropody, dentistry and hair removal at in-store clinics - promising ventures but still on a very small scale.

The down side is that if such services take off, they will make Boots more cyclical - customers cut back on luxuries in tough times. One of the group's strengths has been that its earnings remain stable throughout recessions.

A review of price controls in over-the-counter medicines is due in October; some critics say the company could go the way of another much-loved retail institution - Marks & Spencer.

Boots' shares are trading on about 10 times expected earnings - not a particularly cheap rating. The general outlook on the high street remains patchy, at best, and the momentum in the shares is likely to be shortlived. Sell.

fields.headline: Dot.com pioneers make pay leap
fields.standfirst:
Day one of an exclusive three-part survey of the riches reaped by Britain's business leaders

Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Day one of an exclusive three-part survey of the riches reaped by Britain's business leaders
fields.body:
Chief executives of so-called new economy firms leapt above their old economy peers in this year's Guardian-Inbucon survey of boardroom rewards - predominantly as a result of the inexorable rise in their firms' shares.

By cashing in the options on shares awarded to them when their companies were shadows of their present size, Paul Chisholm, chief executive of Colt Telecom, and Mike Grabiner of Energis were able to make profits of more than £10m each.

Another new economy firm, software house Sage, saw its chief executive take home more than £6.5m.

However, working for an old economy retailer does not appear to hurt one's bank balance. Luc Vandevelde, the new chairman of Marks & Spencer, received £2m for one month's work, thanks to a "golden hello" from the group.

The distinctly old-fashioned Daily Mail empire also figures, with both the chief executive and finance director finding their place in the top 10.

The survey also highlights the globalisation of the boardrooms in the country's top 100 companies and the accompanying trend towards US-style pay deals for executives.

As the survey was published it was revealed that the chief executive of a soon to be stock market-listed company would be paid entirely in the shares of the new company. Peter Giller, the chief executive of International Power - which is being demerged from National Power - could receive £9m of shares if the company's share price doubles in three years.

Such share-only payments were described by industry experts as "unusual" but a reflection of the increasing use of shares and options in pay deals for senior executives.

This trend has been cited as one of the reasons for the move by the Accounting Standards Board, which sets guidelines on accounting practice, to produce controversial proposals to put the cost of options awards in companies' profit and loss accounts. At present they are not shown.

The Department of Trade and Industry is also scrutinising the issue of directors' remuneration and is understood to be close to deciding whether shareholders should be able to veto the awarding of large boardroom pay packets.

While a senior industry source accused the government of "sitting on its hands", Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is understood to be determined to tackle the issue. Sources said he planned to make a statement in the coming weeks.

The chairmen's pay league is led by Gerry Robinson of Granada and Francis Mackay of Compass, whose companies have now merged to allow Granada to spin off part of its media empire.

The media industry also contains the only three executives in the research to receive basic salaries of more than £1m. The three men who make £20,000 a week are Mr Robinson and two EMI directors: Ken Berry and Martin Bandier.

The 16.5% rise in board directors' basic salaries - which make up an ever smaller proportion of their total remuneration - shows that directors' pay continues to outstrip the average wage increases for their employees.

However, Kate Barker, chief executive of the Confederation of British Industry, said that the rises reflected the increasing need of industry to recruit internationally.

As the CBI produced a survey showing that manufacturing pay awards rose to 2.9% in three months to June from 2.7% the previous year, she detected a change in the payment structure lower down the remuneration scale, too. "It's very variable now. It's not just the old RPI [retail price index] plus x; everything is being priced to market."

The Guardian-Inbucon survey is based on information contained in the latest annual reports of companies in the FTSE 100 at the end of June this year. NatWest's last annual report before its takeover by Royal Bank of Scotland was included, however.

In total, the pay of executive directors from 85 companies has been analysed by professional consultants who needed to make their own interpretation of some of the data in the reports and accounts.

The calculations of total compensation for the financial year include base salary, termination payments, basic cash bonuses, deferred bonus scheme payments in cash or shares, the release of awards from long-term incentive plans and gains on options exercised. Options or share awards granted during the year are not included.

Tomorrow: The millionaires' club plus international analysis of boardroom pay

fields.headline: Downtown 81
fields.standfirst: Edinburgh film festival ****Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Edinburgh film festival ****
fields.body:
Downtown 81 is a delightful curio of a movie from the days just before Jean-Michel Basquiat was taken up by the New York art world and lionised as the first great black American painter. He was a 19-year-old graffiti artist and aspiring rock musician when screenwriter Glenn O'Brien and director Edo Bertoglio put together this touching 75-minute vignette. The story, such as it is, has the homeless Basquiat wandering the streets and downtown clubs, selling a painting and meeting a girl.

With a cast of drug dealers, music agents, a vampish European collector and disillusioned musicians, Downtown 81 is both innocent and poignant, given Basquiat's later death from a surfeit of drugs. "I could see the handwriting on the wall," says Basquiat at one point. Eventually he meets his fairy godmother, Debbie Harry, who waves her wand and changes his life with a suitcase of cash.

Downtown 81 captures that New York moment when punk, emerging rap, art school cool and the East Village art and music scenes were at their creative best. There are some great walk-on parts and terrific live music, including Basquiat's own band, Grey.

At the Cameo, Edinburgh (0131-228 4141), tonight,Glasgow Film Theatre (0141-332 8128), on Thursday, and the Filmhouse, Edinburgh (0131-228 2688) on Saturday.

fields.headline: Lena
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Below **

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Pleasance Below **
fields.body:
This is a very strange little number. You can look at it two ways: Carla Lane, queen of the sitcom, has written either an unintentionally bad play, or an anti-sitcom that lays bare the truth behind all those ditsy housewives and mothers in TV comedies whose mild frustrations are apparently the fount of all humour.

It doesn't work, but there is enough here to keep you interested, from Kate Marlow's production, which treats the whole thing as if it were actually TV, to Nichollette Collins's comically deadpan performance, a convincing account of a woman in need of intravenous Prozac. Lena is a middle-aged woman. Her marriage is not unhappy but it has lost all passion. Her children have left home ("Bye Mam, thanks for your life"). She has nothing left but Radio 4 plays and sexual fantasies about Arron, the odd-job gardener, who may or may not be a figment of her imagination.

Most plays about middle-aged women's lives are horribly soft (think Shirley Valentine), but this is a relentless and quite uncomfortable account of a woman trying to hold it all together while she is dying inside. The real tragedy of Lena is not that she has become invisible to the wider world, but that her own family have failed to notice her distress.

Till Monday. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival comedy review: Boom Chicago is Coming

fields.headline: Boom Chicago is Coming
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance One ***
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Pleasance One ***
fields.body:
The queue for Boom Chicago stretches right across the courtyard, so I ask around to find out why this show has become so popular. "I heard about if from a friend," says the French girl next to me. A New Yorker has a similar explanation: "I met one of the guys."

Odd. But there again, word of mouth is so much a part of Boom Chicago's act that it is appropriate that it has also become their advertising. This is improvised comedy that begins when five people from the audience are questioned and filmed. Their "personalities" are then adopted by the cast. Big on comic interplay and rapier-like of wit, the five Americans take us through a series of adventures. Shouted suggestions are then woven into the storylines. However the appeal of Boom Chicago is Coming is very mainstream. Pick Ups and Hiccups, also at the Pleasance from the same company, is the one to queue to see.

Till Sunday. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: John Sutherland: On a writer's triumph

fields.headline: Golden boy who beat the killer eel
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland: On a writer's triumph
fields.trailText: John Sutherland: On a writer's triumph
fields.body:
I've spent the week interviewing Reynolds Price and investigating his literary papers. Price, born in 1933, was one of that golden generation of American novelists (Gore Vidal, William Styron and Truman Capote are others) who seemed to have been blessed in the cradle with genius, physical grace and - what writers need above all - good luck at the outset of their careers.

A Rhodes scholar at Oxford in 1956, Price sent a batch of his unpublished stories to Stephen Spender (then the editor of the magazine Encounter) on the whimsical grounds that he thought the great poet had "the kindest face I have ever seen".

Editorial kindness rarely extends to indulging the egos of hopeful undergraduates, even those with faces as beautiful as the young Price. But Spender read the manuscripts and realising, from page one, that he had discovered a great writer, rushed the stories into print. Like Byron, Reynolds Price awoke and found himself famous. Within 18 months, and at the age of 24, he was hailed as one of the major novelists of his time with A Long and Happy Life (a work which has never been out of print in America since 1962).

Price's career thereafter went swimmingly. He returned to his native North Carolina to take up a position teaching creative writing at his alma mater, Duke University. He wrote novels, won prizes, made heaps of money and had, it seemed, a charmed life. Charm and a bubbling wit were what everyone noted about him. "You make any house you are in golden," Spender once told him.

In 1984, Price's world disintegrated. He was diagnosed with cancer - a one-foot-long, slimy growth "as thick as a pencil" had braided itself round his spinal cord. He called it "the eel". Price was, literally, at the cutting edge of oncology. Duke's medical school led the world in the surgical treatment of cancer. Its expert scalpel and radiotherapy killed the eel. That was the good news. The bad news was that the 4,000 rads (units of radiation) bombarded into Price's neck destroyed his nervous system.

It was the cruellest of cures. At 51, Price found himself cancer-free but paraplegic. Other Americans might have enriched themselves with a vindictive malpractice suit. Reynolds confronted his condition not as an aggrieved patient, but as an author. Out of the experience of losing his lower body, he wrote a book with the ironic title A Whole New Life.

Reading it is painful, humbling and intensely uplifting. As "an American with disability" (as the federal statute puts it), Price prefers the honest Anglo-Saxon terms "gimp" and "cripple". The most eloquent of writers, when occasion calls, he uses language with a thug's brutality. Talking of his sanitary arrangements he notes: "Since the muscles that expel faeces from the lower intestines are inactive in most of the paralysed, some form of rubber-gloved manual removal is generally required. Whatever the individual gimp hits on for a workable method, he or she quickly becomes as familiar with his own piss and shit as any Paleolithic cave-dweller."

If - as I have been doing over the last week - you converse with Price, you are aware of two things. He smiles and cracks jokes (hilariously funny jokes) continuously. And he writhes with pain continuously. His spine is destroyed, but still hurts excruciatingly: the eel's revenge. He refuses to use painkillers on the grounds that they dull his mind.

S ince embarking on his whole new life, Price has, in most critics' judgment, written even better than he did in his old life. It's an extraordinary achievement. We ritually salute handicapped bravery - but often with a secret condescension. We know that those athletes in the Paralympics couldn't really compete with their unhandicapped colleagues.

Last week some magnificently obstinate wheelchair-using American hikers battled their way to a peak in New Hampshire to force the Appalachian Mountain Club to do their legal duty and install a handicapped toilet, with grab bars, at 3,800 feet. But, in our hearts, we know that a mountaineer in a wheelchair is never going to be as good as someone with the use of his legs.

With Price (and, I suspect, with Stephen Hawking) it is different. The human mind can conquer disability and soar above it. But don't take my word for it, get hold of one of the 20-odd books that Reynolds Price has written since 1984 and find out for yourself.

webTitle: Indoor matches on Tykes wish list

fields.headline: Indoor matches on Tykes wish list
fields.standfirst: County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText: Just hours before South Africa beat Australia by eight runs at Melbourne's indoor Colonial Stadium, Yorkshire's challenge to Surrey's supremacy in the County Championship was again thwarted by the elements.
fields.body:
If only the much-hyped redevelopment plans for Headingley included a roof, Yorkshire fans must be wishing.

Just hours before South Africa beat Australia by eight runs at Melbourne's indoor Colonial Stadium to tie the historic one-day series 1-1, Yorkshire's challenge to Surrey's supremacy in the County Championship was again thwarted by the elements.

Having washed out the third day against Leicestershire, rain again hit Grace Road on Saturday's final day. There was time enough for Darren Lehmann to blaze 18 fours and a six in a belligerent 115 - securing three vital bonus points along the way - but not to force a result.

Yorkshire are now 18 points adrift and, even if they do beat Surrey next week, they will need the runaway leaders to slip up more than once to have any chance of September glory.

Third-placed Lancashire at least kept their hopes flickering, beating Kent by 154 runs at Old Trafford. With England's selectors mulling over their squad for the subcontinent, Chris Schofield gave a timely reminder of his precocious talents, following up his unbeaten 70 with four for 25.

Justin Langer's unbeaten 69 off 36 balls set up an enterprising Middlesex declaration at Edgbaston yesterday, but the visitors remain bottom of the Second Division after Warwickshire held on at 191 for five.

 Indian players involved in match-fixing or betting will be banned for between five years and life under a new code of conduct finalised yesterday.

fields.headline: National League  round-up
fields.trailText: If Matthew Hoggard still rues that wayward second spell at Lord's in his one and only Test, he is refusing to show it. The right-arm paceman, written off by some experts as a short-term England prospect, kept Yorkshire firmly in First Division title contention as Leicestershire were skittled for 53 on a treacherous Grace Road pitch.
fields.body:
If Matthew Hoggard still rues that wayward second spell at Lord's in his one and only Test, he is refusing to show it. The right-arm paceman, written off by some experts as a short-term England prospect, kept Yorkshire firmly in First Division title contention as Leicestershire were skittled for 53 on a treacherous Grace Road pitch.

Trevor Ward and Darren Maddy top-scored with eight, as Hoggard tore through the top-order with five for 28 and Chris Silverwood, another forgotten England quick, cleaned up the rest to finish with four for 11. With premature climaxes all the rage at present, Yorkshire knocked off the target with eight wickets in hand, the match all over in little more than 2 hours.

Sussex continue to find life without Michael Bevan unappetising. A run-a-ball 84 by David Sales at Eastbourne lifted his competition average to 74 and guided Northamptonshire to a comfortable six-wicket win, after the hosts collapsed to 196 all out.

Alan Mullally was another former England bowler who prospered in the Second Division, taking four for 30 as Hampshire cruised to a rare six-wicket victory over Essex at Colchester.

Paul Reiffel captured some of the season's best figures with 7-3-8-3 as Nottinghamshire beat Glamorgan by eight wickets at a wet Colwyn Bay, while Surrey predictably secured promotion with a six-wicket win over Derbyshire.

fields.headline: The danger of quick cricket
fields.standfirst: Bad pitches make Tests exciting but they don't make good players, says  David Hopps
fields.trailText: Bad pitches make Tests exciting but they don't make good players, says David Hopps.
fields.body:
As cricketing parties go, Headingley 2000 was about as wild as it gets: West Indies overpowered in two days of unadulterated hedonism; memories of England's innings victory both vivid and confused; Test cricket in an adrenalin rush. But we ignore the deeper significance of last week's events at our peril.

England have had too few wonderful days recently to care for too much sober reassessment, but Test cricket cannot live so hard and fast for long without doing itself irreparable damage.

That much was immediately obvious to the man in charge of the catering at Headingley. "What can I do with 400 cabbages and two tons of tomatoes?" sighed Shaun Callaghan on Friday evening. The England and Wales Cricket Board, who have lost £1.5m-£2m in a summer of premature Test finishes, will be concerned not as much by cabbages as cabbage patches. The standard of international pitches in England is a cause for great concern. And it will preoccupy club treasurers as much as it does club captains.

Attendances in the West Indies series will have dropped by one-third, compared with the last West Indies tour in 1995. That could reduce the average Test handout to the 18 first-class counties next year by around £50,000 at a time when financially pressed counties are being urged to implement ambitious programmes of player and ground development.

The interest generated by a compulsive series arguably compensates for the individual frustration of those holding weekend Test tickets with no Test to go to. But extraordinary events should remain precisely that. Instead, early finishes have become the norm.

That England, themselves unpredictable, have hosted a succession of weak tourists, in New Zealand, Zimbabwe and the West Indies, offers just part of the explanation.

Drawn Tests do not fit easily with the modern mind. Forty-three per cent of Tests finished as draws between 1946 and 1990 but this became unsustainable in an era where, whatever the sport, spectators and TV companies alike demand winners. Since the start of the 90s, the percentage of draws has fallen to 35%, a large proportion rain-affected. With one-day methods also embedded in players' hearts and minds, the downturn might still have some way to go.

Conflicting messages have emerged from Headingley. Yes, West Indies' second innings was blown aside by high-quality swing bowling at speed; the new-ball partnership of Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick increasingly flirts with world-class standards. Yes, West Indies' defensive technique and mental strength was lacking.

But for Jimmy Adams to insist that "the Headingley pitch was fine" was not a vote of approval, merely a recognition that West Indies must first examine themselves. This Headingley pitch did not quite possess the malevolence of many of its notorious predecessors but it was another mediocre Test surface - damp underneath its misleadingly hard, dry crust. If the pitch starts damp, it seams alarmingly. If it is too dry, it cracks and bounces unevenly. Heavy loam soils, which prevent consistent grass growth, are regarded with suspicion, as are modern balls.

Efforts have been made to tip the balance back to the batsmen in recent years by reducing the prominence of the seam. But in most modern balls, a centre of bonded cork pulp has replaced the traditional strips of cork, enabling the ball to keep its hardness longer. The advent of reverse swing in mid-innings, as exemplified by Craig White in West Indies' first innings, also means that batsmen rarely enjoy the undemanding sessions of old.

That does not excuse the failures of English groundsmanship. Football has moved on from muddy centre circles, but cricket remains incapable of consistently producing surfaces offering an equal challenge between bat and ball. Uneven bounce encourages fatalism, and an attitude of gather while ye can, in all but the finest technical players.

Poor pitches at club level, where the lack of a pyramid system breeds ignorance and idleness, have long stymied the development of young English players. "Result" pitches at county level have been rife, as counties respond to the more competitive culture of two divisions by exchanging blow for blow on substandard surfaces.

Until recently, though, covered Test pitches have been relatively sound and, England (traditionally, a land of medium-paced seamers) have not performed particularly well on them. Now Michael Atherton, an England batsman and former captain, can write that since the Australian tour of 1997, things have become so bad that every Test pitch apart from Trent Bridge and Old Trafford should be dug up.

If the Oval - a fitting venue for the final Test of the series - can produce fast, dry and true surfaces, then the same should be true of every English ground. No one has yet suggested that Kennington possesses its own Australian-style micro-climate. It is time for the ECB to impose itself. Never mind centrally contracted players. It is time for centrally contracted groundsmen.

Now Michael Atherton, an England batsman and former captain, can write that since the Australian tour of 1997, things have become so bad that every Test pitch apart from Trent Bridge and Old Trafford should be dug up. If the Oval - a fitting venue for the final Test of the series - can produce fast, dry and true surfaces, then the same should be true of every English ground. No one has yet suggested that Kennington possesses its own Australian-style micro-climate. It is time for the ECB to impose itself. Never mind centrally contracted players. It is time for centrally contracted groundsmen.

webTitle: Cox catches fire to lead Somerset into unknown

fields.headline: Cox catches fire to lead Somerset into unknown
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 227-9
Worcestershire 174
Somerset win by 53 runs
National League First Division points table
fields.trailText: Somerset's proficient win by 53 runs took them to the top of the First Division of the National League at the expense of Worcestershire. But they are not temperamentally or historically used to high altitudes and must now demonstrate a fibre which, at times in the past, has seemed elusive. Their captain Jamie Cox, who followed his half-century with three catches, set the right example.
fields.body:
Somerset's proficient win by 53 runs took them to the top of the First Division of the National League at the expense of Worcestershire. But they are not temperamentally or historically used to high altitudes and must now demonstrate a fibre which, at times in the past, has seemed elusive. Their captain Jamie Cox, who followed his half-century with three catches, set the right example.

Worcestershire's hopes evaporated when Graeme Hick drove straight to cover for Cox to hug the catch with visible delight. Vikram Solanki paraded some attractive strokes before again disappointing his local admirers as he snicked to Rob Turner, standing up to Marcus Trescothick.

After that they never really looked like winning, though David Leatherdale did his best until also caught at the wicket, this time off Ian Blackwell, who finished with four for 36.

Worcestershire had been far too philanthropic at the start of Somerset's innings. There were three wides in each of the first two overs, one landing beyond the keeper and going for four. After four overs Somerset were 36 for none; Kabir Ali and Chris Liptrot rapidly withdrew from the attack.

But Trescothick and Mark Lathwell continued to off- and on-drive eagerly, doing in tandem what the Somerset faithful had dreamed of six years ago. Trescothick clipped to mid-wicket with his first false stroke and Lathwell, going for a second run, was beaten by Richard Illingworth's throw.

It was a day of wayward running. Somerset lost four that way, three to Leatherdale's alertness, and should have scored more than 227. But Worcestershire settled after their loose start, mainly due to Stuart Lampitt, Illingworth and Leatherdale, who dismissed Cox and Michael Burns after they had both reached 50.

By the high-harvest standards of last season, this has been a more subdued summer for Cox. He is an orthodox batsman, never remotely in a hurry, yet he progresses all the same, and here the more pragmatic Burns was the ideal foil.

Just as well for Somerset, as the pair's successors proved transitory: Blackwell was run out without facing a ball, Keith Parsons swung recklessly and Graham Rose was caught at leg-slip to a ball that was almost a wide.

webTitle: Strachan nude? Julius Caesar haircuts? It's gonna be a long, hard...

fields.headline: Strachan nude? Julius Caesar haircuts? It's gonna be a long, hard...
fields.trailText: If I am not careful this could turn out to be the only column in the British press this week not to include a Big Brother reference, so how about this: Gordon Strachan as Nichola?
fields.body:
If I am not careful this could turn out to be the only column in the British press this week not to include a Big Brother reference, so how about this: Gordon Strachan as Nichola?

Think about it; the exuberance, the excitability, the sometimes irritating readiness to lay bare their emotions on TV. Obviously you couldn't imagine Strachan doing naked clay painting (well, you could, though it is not advisable unless under qualified medical supervision), but apart from that the Big Brother evictee and the Coventry manager appear to have much in common.

Strachan, caught by the Match Of The Day cameras after the home defeat by Middlesbrough and nominated by several experts for eviction from the Premiership, was more than ever in need of a big hug. "No one, unless they manage a team, can know how I feel," he said. "No one - not an assistant manager, a player, anyone. They do not know how I feel at this moment. They've not got a clue."

Blimey, thought this viewer, save some for the rest of the season, Gordon. There are 37 matches to go. Or, in the parlance of almost every analyst interviewed on the Premiership's opening day: "It's going to be a long hard season for them." This was routinely applied not just to Coventry, but to Bradford, Ipswich, Manchester City and any team with a less than glittering recent history.

Other expressions that were de rigueur on opening day included "Manchester United will be the team to beat" and, on the influx of foreign players, "but will they be able to turn it on on a wet Wednesday night at the Dell?" For variety this was occasionally, thrillingly, altered to: "But will they fancy it on a cold January afternoon up in Middlesbrough?" For Screen Break's cliche-watch, it is clearly going to be a long... well, you know the rest.

I do love the start of a new season, though. For those of us not particularly attached to any summer sport, it gives Saturday its focus back, as well as keeping us out of Ikea. It is also the one Saturday in the season when levels of anxiety are way below levels of anticipation.

Poor start? Pah, plenty of time to recover once the new signings settle in. I cancelled all arrangements and was up bright and early for Soccer AM on Sky, which I find a constant delight.

On Saturday, the programme lampooned the ludicrous practice of displaying league tables at an early stage of the season by showing the table before a ball had been kicked, with the teams, all on zero points, arranged in strict alphabetical order. Thus, when they went through the fixtures, they were able to say things like "And West Ham need those points badly to get away from the foot of the table" and "Charlton v Man City, a massive six-pointer".

A little joke, but so patently relished by Soccer AM's personable presenters Tim Lovejoy and Helen Chamberlain (Hells Bells to us habitues), that the enjoyment became infectious. I like their phono no-nos, too. These are topics or expressions deemed too careworn for use in the programme's live phone-in. This week they banned the phrase "the usual suspects" in any discussion about who might challenge for the Premiership, and disqualified any caller who wanted to talk about the number of foreigners in the Premier League. Spot on, I thought, and continued to think later listening to some of the more tedious phone-ins on TalkSport and Radio Five Live.

And then, just when I was in danger of getting jaded, along came Match Of The Day with a new title sequence that had a distinctly heritage feel to it - a few sepia images and the voice of Kenneth Wolstenholme - possibly intended as a reminder to the Premier League of all the tradition they are junking by going for ITV's cash.

Not that MOTD seemed downbeat about their last season in the Premiership. Gary, Alan and Trevor were all deeply tanned, so the threat of the axe had obviously not prevented them summering in agreeably warm spots. Hansen had even splashed out on a fetching new hairstyle, although my daughter - something of an expert in these matters - tells me the Julius Caesar cut is "so last year". George Clooney was apparently wearing it like that three films ago.

All the excitement of the first Premiership games and Alan's retro haircut meant that I slept soundly through Prince Naseem's fight, although I did catch yesterday morning's repeat and can tell you that Naseem, in Arabic, means "the gentle breeze". The Prince informed us of this in his post-fight interview, missing the irony of the fact that the gentle breeze's opponent was laid out on a stretcher with a neck brace on and tubes coming out of his nose.

Naseem-Sanchez was an exciting fight, no mistake, but at moments like that professional boxing increasingly seems "so last century". It is somehow shaming to pay to see two boys knocking seven bells out of each other for no good reason. Mind you, Nick v Craig in the Big Brother house; I'd pay for that.

fields.headline: United hit the ground running
fields.standfirst:
Johnsen and Cole satisfy champions' best crowd for 64 years
Van Nistelrooy back on track
fields.trailText: Man Utd 2 - 0 Newcastle
fields.body:
All that changes at the Premiership's largest place of worship is the size of the congregation. Yesterday Old Trafford's biggest crowd for 64 years watched Manchester United pick up the thread of success with the air of men who did not intend dropping any more stitches this season than they did last.

The latest expansion of United's stadium has raised its capacity to 68,000 and yesterday's attendance of 67,477 was last exceeded for a match against Manchester City way back in 1936. That was the year of the abdication but as Sir Alex Ferguson's side first sped then strolled past Newcastle United there was no sign whatsoever that a similar thought had occurred to the champions for six of the last eight seasons. This crown is not on offer.

Before now Manchester United, like Liverpool in their title-winning days, have been known to start a new season looking a little hungover from the previous campaign. Yesterday, however, Ferguson's players moved with the speed and perception of men for whom the task of prolonging their near-monopoly of the Premiership had not come a moment too soon.

While Newcastle, revived by Bobby Robson last season following the fall of Ruud Gullit and a dangerous flirtation with relegation, showed considerably more determination than they had done in losing 5-1 at Old Trafford a year earlier, their defeat would have been equally heavy but for the goalkeeping of Shay Given and the opposition calling it a day once they had taken a 2-0 lead.

Certainly Robson knew the truth of it and virtually admitted as much. "Manchester United had better movement and better quality," he said. "Really, they played quite beautifully. They're just a class act. If my players needed to see the sort of team we want to become then they've seen it today."

So far as Manchester United's football in the first half was concerned this was fair comment. Ferguson hopes that this season Ryan Giggs, now 26, will embark on the golden age of an already glittering career and to judge by the way the Welshman consistently ran at and past defenders a similar thought has occurred to Giggs.

With Andy Cole at his industrious best, Roy Keane omnipotent in midfield and Jaap Stam taking advantage of the more assured presence of Ronny Johnsen alongside him to make several surging runs from the back, United steadily rolled back Newcastle with passing and movement of a familiar but still exceptional quality.

On his own admission Robson employed a sweeper system "with the idea of getting a 0-0 or a 1-1". The trouble was his three central defenders were too sluggish as a unit to cope with the swift interchanges of passes and positions which are the champions' stock-in-trade.

Yet when Manchester United did take the lead after 20 minutes the goal came from a simple set-piece involving little subtlety, just routine opportunism from a centre-back. First Stam was granted a free header as he met a corner from David Beckham on the right with a brisk nod which saw Given arch back to touch the ball over the crossbar. Another corner, from Beckham on the left, found Stam distracting the Newcastle defence, leaving Johnsen to produce a header which Given this time could only help into the net.

A rich vein of football from Ferguson's team followed. Ten minutes before half-time Giggs, half-stumbling as he gained possession on the left, began a multi-passing movement which ended with his shot striking the foot of the near post after Paul Scholes had laid the ball in from the right.

While all this was happening Fabien Barthez, the goalkeeping Marshal of France signed by Ferguson in the hope that he will prove the real successor to Peter Schmeichel, was all but a spectator in his first home match as a Manchester United player. None of Newcastle's finishing seriously tested his capabilities and Barthez's most impressive contribution came from the length and accuracy of his clearances. "He can," as Ferguson observed, "play through-passes from the edge of his own box."

A goal down at half-time, and with little prospect of drawing level, Robson replaced Alain Goma with Kieron Dyer clearly in the hope of giving Alan Shearer a modicum of support in his lone struggle against Stam and Johnsen. Carl Cort, Newcastle's £7m summer signing from Wimbledon, showed some useful touches at the start and the willingness of Daniel Cordone, the Argentine signed on loan from Racing Club, to join the attack briefly disturbed United but that was all.

Newcastle's best chance of at least extending Manchester United a little more in the second half came when Nolberto Solano, who had just come on for Robert Lee, appeared near the right-hand byline on the hour. Shearer was in space near goal but the Peruvian failed to get the ball to him.

Manchester United should have acquired the comfort of a second goal earlier than they did. Given kept out a cross-shot from Beckham and then had to move quickly to spare Nikos Dabizas the embarrassment of an own goal after the Greek had intercepted a cross meant for Cole with a header Cole could hardly have bettered.

After 63 minutes Cole fed a return pass to Giggs whose cross was intended for Teddy Sheringham but instead found Cole heading over from an awkward angle. Never mind: six minutes later Cole worked another one-two with Giggs and this time scored sweetly.

An impressive start by Manchester United then, although their mettle remains to be tested more rigorously by more likely rivals than Newcastle United, not to mention the Champions League. Yesterday an old foe, Eusebio, presented life achievement awards to Bobby Charlton, Denis Law and George Best. As if Newcastle did not have enough to cope with.
