fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy back on track
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham's delight at starting Manchester United's first Premiership game of the season will have been tempered by the news that United have invited Ruud van Nistelrooy to train with them in October with a view to resurrecting his £18.5m move to Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham's delight at starting Manchester United's first Premiership game of the season will have been tempered by the news that United have invited Ruud van Nistelrooy to train with them in October with a view to resurrecting his £18.5m move to Old Trafford.

The PSV Eindhoven striker's transfer was abandoned in April when he refused an exploratory knee operation. After returning to Holland the 24-year-old then collapsed in training with a cruciate knee ligament injury that also kept him out of the Dutch Euro 2000 squad.

Van Nistelrooy was expected to be out of action for up to a year and Sir Alex Ferguson persuaded the 34-year-old Sheringham to sign a new one-year deal, despite interest from several other clubs, promising him that he would not sign another striker this season.

But Van Nistelrooy's comeback is well ahead of schedule, and Ferguson said: "If all goes well then the deal will be back on."

The United manager, who plans to fly to Holland this week to talk to Van Nistelrooy, added: "We need to see him prove he is capable of returning to full fitness and then we can talk."

fields.headline: Third Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Mansfield came back from two down to earn a 3-3 draw at Barnet, who moved up to fourth place thanks to three goals in 17 first-half minutes and despite slipping into arrears when Mark Blake scored after five minutes.
fields.body:
Mansfield came back from two down to earn a 3-3 draw at Barnet, who moved up to fourth place thanks to three goals in 17 first-half minutes and despite slipping into arrears when Mark Blake scored after five minutes.

Mark Arber equalised, Sam Stockley hit the second and Scott McGleish appeared to have made it safe. But Darrell Clarke and Chris Greenacre came up with second-half goals to split the points.

Rochdale's Tony Ellis and Brighton's Andy Crosby were sent off for violent conduct after 20 minutes, by which time the score was 1-1, the £100,000 Bobby Zamora equalising Tony Ford's header for the visitors and then hitting the winner on the stroke of half-time.

Scunthorpe's Nigel Pepper was sent of for violent conduct after only 15 minutes but the 10 men still overcame Jan Molby's Kidderminster 2-0 and are second.

Chesterfield, relegated last season, are top after a 2-1 win at Hartlepool who led through Kevin Henderson. Steve Tutill levelled, however, and Roger Willis hit the winner. Leyton Orient joined them on maximum points, a first-half Matt Lockwood penalty doing for Carlisle .

Cardiff, title favourites, were held at home by John Murphy's last-minute equaliser for Blackpool.

fields.headline: Second Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Peterborough United only picked up a point from yesterday's hard-fought fixture with visiting Bristol Rovers, and that despite going a goal to the good after 20 minutes. A cross from their left-back Adam Drury fell invitingly for Francis Green, who tucked the ball inside Nick Culkin's right-hand post from 15 yards. But eight minutes later it was all square when Micky Evans, on-loan from West Brom, latched on to Andy Thomson's pass and finished from 12 yards. Andy Clarke, the former Wimbledon striker, restored Posh's lead six minutes after the interval, when he dispossessed Steve Foster on the edge of the area and made ground before cracking the ball past Culkin. But minutes later Nathan Ellington outpaced Simon Rea on the left and cut inside before tucking the ball under Mark Tyler.

fields.headline: First Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Preston have taken to living in more exalted company with some comfort and Jonathan Macken, who scored 25 goals for last season's Second Division champions, hit two more as they beat Sheffield United 3-0 at Deepdale to maintained their 100% record and share top place with Fulham.
fields.body:
Preston have taken to living in more exalted company with some comfort and Jonathan Macken, who scored 25 goals for last season's Second Division champions, hit two more as they beat Sheffield United 3-0 at Deepdale to maintained their 100% record and share top place with Fulham.

Macken, a £250,000 signing from Manchester United in July 1997, also scored in last week's victory at Grimsby.

"It's over 20 years since we were in this division, and we are we are enjoying our selves," said Preston's manager David Moyes. "But we are not kidding ourselves. We've only just started and there's a long way to go."

There are seven north-west clubs in the division this season and six of them are in the top eight, with Stan Ternent's Burnley also undefeated.

They beat Wimbledon 1-0 thanks to a well-taken goal from Paul Weller, a bitter pill for Wimbledon's manager Terry Burton to swallow. "We looked a team of strangers," he conceded. "No goals and no wins from the first two games is a disappointment, but when we get some players back we should be OK."

Blackburn are also unbeaten, but their 0-0 draw at Crewe was overshadowed by the death of their benefactor Jack Walker. "The players did their best in the circumstances," the manager Graeme Souness claimed. "But I thought their minds weren't entirely on the game. They were quiet at training and at the hotel. But they did themselves credit and were disappointed because they wanted to win it for him and the fans."

Bolton remain undefeated due to a 2-0 win at West Bromwich after goals from Isaiah Rankin and Gareth Farrelly, while Stockport held Wolves 1-1 at Edgeley Park.

Tranmere are also unbeaten after a 3-2 home win against Gillingham, who had Barry Ashby sent off. "You can't afford to do things like that," said Andy Hessenthaler, the Gills player-manager who has yet to win a point."

Norwich and Forest were goalless at Carrow Road and a late equaliser from David Smith earned Grimsby their point at Portsmouth .

webTitle: Charlton show the passion for big stage

fields.headline: Charlton show the passion for big stage
fields.standfirst:
After all the big talk, big signings and big build-up, City are blown away on their Premiership return
Weah not very good - and it hurts
fields.trailText: Charlton 4 - 0 Man City
fields.body:
Motivating highly paid players to perform in a league which is hyped to the hilt and where staying up is deemed even more important than surviving Big Brother should not be difficult. On this evidence, though, Joe Royle still has work to do, while Alan Curbishley should be giving masterclasses.

Charlton's four-goal romp on their return to the Premiership, against an insipid Manchester City, was a lesson to their more-fancied rivals that heart and passion still count for much in the frenzied environs of the top flight. Sublime skills were at a premium on Saturday and, while Charlton rose to the occasion, City froze.

Curbishley insisted afterwards that simply being in the Premiership is motivation enough and Charlton will be trying their utmost to prove this result was not a fluke at Everton on Wednesday.

"If you ask my players what they missed most about the Premiership I'm sure to a man they would say 'the atmospheres, the packed houses, the players they are playing against'," said Curbishley.

"When I wrote up on the board before the match that we were against Weah, Wanchope and names like that, that's what they want to be playing against.

"The Premiership is a whole new world compared to the First Division and that's what the players enjoy. Obviously the money's important as well but if you say to them Wednesday and Everton away, they will go 'Goodison, fantastic, packed house, Gazza, Ferguson, great'."

Surely Walter Smith's side will give Charlton a stiffer test than City - it would be hard not to - and the excited throngs at the Valley will have been sobered by the thought they have been here before. Two seasons ago Charlton were top after two games having beaten Southampton 5-0; eight months later they were relegated. The Saints are the next visitors to the Valley.

However, the true worth of Charlton's performance was not easy to assess given the paucity of the opposition. Each of the home side's goals owed something to inept defending, with the sluggish Steve Howey, a £2m buy from Newcastle, looking like a startled rabbit whenever Kevin Lisbie, Charlton's seventh-choice striker, ran at him.

Royle's motivational techniques, which have involved speakers and a sports psychologist in the pre-season, clearly failed on Saturday. "Perhaps we weren't up for it as much as Charlton," said Alf-Inge Haaland. They appeared to still be in a different league.

Lisbie had hit the bar and the impressive Claus Jensen seen a free-kick tipped over before Andy Hunt opened the scoring.

The striker was fed by Jensen and rounded the static Spencer Prior and Richard Edghill before shooting past Nicky Weaver in the City goal.

Lisbie, again, and Richard Rufus should have done better with clear headers before John Robinson doubled Charlton's lead, Weaver scuffing an attempt to clear his shot.

Dean Kiely in the Charlton goal tipped a Paulo Wanchope header on to the post, but Charlton strolled to victory with Mark Kinsella coolly scoring the third with the outside of his right boot and Graham Stuart converting a penalty after Kinsella had been brought down by Weaver.

"We let ourselves down," said Prior, who could have a new central-defensive partner, Paul Ritchie, who completes his move from Rangers today, for Wednesday's home game against Sunderland. "We are lucky we have still got 37 games to put it right."

This was City's one consolation. They are back to square one this morning; Charlton are in the zone already.

webTitle: Weah not very good - and it hurts

fields.headline: Weah not very good - and it hurts
fields.trailText: 2pm: The sun's shining, in every possible way. "We always win when it's sunny, win when it's sunny," sing the ecstatic Blues. Old songs are adapted for new glories. "Weah on the march with Joe's army, Weah going to Wembley." Not only has the former world player of the year signed for the Blues, but he's a City fan. All those years ago, as a little boy in Liberia, he was shouting for Frannie and King Colin. City are back.
fields.body:
2pm: The sun's shining, in every possible way. "We always win when it's sunny, win when it's sunny," sing the ecstatic Blues. Old songs are adapted for new glories. "Weah on the march with Joe's army, Weah going to Wembley." Not only has the former world player of the year signed for the Blues, but he's a City fan. All those years ago, as a little boy in Liberia, he was shouting for Frannie and King Colin. City are back.

2.55: Weah shakes hands with the players. Such style, such dignity, such respect.

3.45: "It'll be all right!" says Mark, who is teaching himself the art of positive thinking. "How?" asks bewildered Bill, a Blue who has sneaked into the ground disguised as a photographer. We're 2-0 down, playing worse than our worst nightmares. The defence is non-existent. So is the midfield. Weah seems to be out for a late summer stroll before retirement.

4.45: 4-0. Bloody Blues, bloody football, bloody life. Since when was hope a crime. I feel like a Watford fan. "We are top," shouts one of their lot. Yeh, and you know where that leaves us.

5.15: Joe admits we were poor, that there was no understanding, but what can you expect when four players are making their debuts. Ah, so that's why Weah was shaking hands - he'd never met any of the team before. Joe says City could have had three penalties, and we get the giggles. Nice try, Joe, a shocker might have summed it up best, though.

6.0: On the train an elderly chap who looks as if he's spent the afternoon on the bowling green asks if we're all right. "Not really," says big Jeff. "Fookin' Blues," says the elegant gent. "Every fookin' time. Just when we begin to fookin' believe in ourselves, splat. Exactly the fookin' same in fookin' '37. Always been a Jekyll and fookin' Hyde team. Won the fookin' championship and went down the year after."

Big Jeff starts singing the surreal song of denial from the bad old days: "We are not, we're not really here." Only this time he's singing "We-ah, We-ah not really here." Well, it is five years since he was world player of the year, and whatever happens he's still a Blue.

7.0: The inquest. We air our grievances. "Why was Joe wearing a leisure shirt and slacks rather than a suit," asks Johnny Brice. "Gives the wrong impression." Come to mention it, why did he say to the reporter that it's only a game?

"The worst thing is they didn't look like they cared," says Mike, a gentleman with murderous thoughts about Richard Edghill. Anything positive? "Wanchope," says Johnny. "Then again I'm worried about the way he postures at the crowd... a bit Premiership, a bit big-time."

Other positives. If we lost every game 4-0 this season, we'd still be a division better off than we were two seasons ago. And it's only a couple of weeks back that the august seer, Kevin Keegan, tipped us as title contenders. Then again, maybe we'll forget that.

"We won't play as bad again all season, that's for sure," says Mark, but we're not so sure he's sure. On the way home I shut my eyes and pretend it's Saturday morning, but all I can see is big Jeff getting off the train a couple of hours back. "Got to laugh haven't you," he said, with a tear in his eye, before taking two fingers, making an imaginary gun and shooting himself in the head. City till I die.

webTitle: Vialli prepares for rule of iron

fields.headline: Vialli prepares for rule of iron
fields.trailText: Chelsea 4 - 2 West Ham
fields.body:
No one could ever accuse Gianluca Vialli of not trying to master the English language. After this hard fought win over West Ham, Chelsea's have-a-go manager turned to the challenge of describing their next opponents, scheduled for tomorrow night. After rummaging through his under-stocked mental phrase book, Vialli decided on "the unbearable tempo of Bradford".

It sounds like a companion volume to The Unbearable Lightness of Being. But then Vialli sought to sum up the qualities Chelsea needed in order to counter Bradford's unbearable beings. Seamlessly he moved from books to film. For surely "the iron fist", was a second world war movie made in the 70s starring Roger Moore and James Coburn. If it wasn't, it should have been.

Maybe it's not too late to make it. Vialli could star. In keeping with Pinewood tradition, he has already shown himself a leader by example. Saturday's absence from the team or bench of Frank Leboeuf was a product of the iron fist being raised if ever there was one, the manager clearly punishing the Frenchman's anti-Vialli outburst last week.

"It is important to send messages to the opposition," said Vialli. He was speaking about how the team play, but could just as easily have been referring to Leboeuf, whose Stamford Bridge future must now be in doubt.

Vialli's point about the iron fist is that, in the pursuit of the title, this is now more important than playing fancy football. "We are labelled in a certain way sometimes and we want to prove to everybody that we are a different team this season," he explained. "Especially when you play at Bradford or at other places where you know it's going to be particularly hard physically and the tempo is going to be unbearable, we have to show that we can cope.

"If we go there, play well and win, then future matches will be easier for us because the opposition will be a bit more apprehensive about playing us."

That message emanated loud and clear from the Bridge on Saturday when Chelsea beat West Ham not by the quality of their football, but by more than matching Harry Redknapp's quality side for resolve and spirit. Add a measure of luck and two pieces of thrilling individual skill, and Chelsea embraced all the ingredients needed to win the Premiership title.

The luck came on the half-hour when Shaka Hislop upended Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. The offence looked to be just outside the area. But the referee Mr Barber pointed to the spot and Hasselbaink's penalty - his first Premiership instalment on his £15 million fee - ended Chelsea's struggle for a breakthrough.

West Ham were rewarded for their persistence and imagination just after the break when Davor Suker cleverly fed Fredric Kanoute, who in turn found the third member of Redknapp's bold three-man strike-force, Paolo di Canio. The Italian coolly stroked the ball home without a blue shirt in sight.

Chelsea then had to dig deep as West Ham sensed a shift in the balance of power. Ed de Goey, who had already denied Suker, pulled off another save to thwart Kanoute before Chelsea regained the ascendancy thanks to the first piece of individual skill, Gianfranco Zola bending a tapped free-kick around the Hammers wall to leave Hislop standing.

Enter another of Vialli's summer signings: Mario Stanic. Strong on the ground and in the air, the Croatian showed he can score too. Picking up the ball about 40 yards out, he flicked it on to his knee, bounced it there for a second, dropped it to his foot and rifled a volley past Hislop.

West Ham did not give up. De Goey saved from Michael Carrick before Kanoute headed home Di Canio's cross. But Chelsea had the last word. Tore Andre Flo hit the post, then Stanic headed in Roberto di Matteo's free-kick.

webTitle: Spurs' little big man shows stature but needs support

fields.headline: Spurs' little big man shows stature but needs support
fields.trailText: Tottenham 3 - 1 Ipswich
fields.byline: Russell Thomas at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
A little more than two hours into the new season, George Graham hammered on in inimitable fashion about "the team ethic" and "sacrifices", beliefs that he insists his No11 wholeheartedly shares. For all that, Sergei Rebrov is patently first among equals.

With his quickness and cleverness, the £11m Ukrainian helped Graham win this opening battle and, with it, the PR war in this post-Ginola era. Save for a brief mention in the manager's programme notes - "I felt that the time was right for David to move on" - the Frenchman's name remained unspoken.

Enter Rebrov instead, a small striker almost lost amid the larger physiques of his new team-mates. You wondered again how he came to be here. Surely it was not the challenge of the likes of Ipswich Town that drew him to north London. Nor surely the man-mountains Hermann Hreidarsson and Titus Bramble in the visitors' defence, who seemed to glower down on the newcomer.

Ninety minutes later another question arose: Rebrov can read the game, but can Spurs read him? The rampaging Stephen Carr could, on one occasion streaming on to the Ukrainian's pass to hit Tottenham's second goal. Two minutes earlier came a delicious foretaste: a sudden shot, delivered by Rebrov with the outside of his right foot from 20 yards, that landed on the crossbar.

Graham eagerly seized upon that startling moment as "showing the kind of class he's got". The manager conceded that Rebrov could have had a hat-trick - once, with time to spare, he badly miscued a volley - but it seemed churlish to pursue this. As Graham insisted: "He's a team player." And, after all, Spurs had fought back to beat a team who asked some awkward questions.

Ultimately the killing goal came from Les Ferdinand's almost forgotten locker of powerful headers. But given the fragility of Ipswich's defence, it was difficult to assess whether Spurs can fulfil their manager's aim of rising from 10th position to "round about the top six, or in the top six".

That seems a modest target for Spurs fans weaned on grander traditions. Rebrov, Graham suggests, is a symbol of the ambition he intends to pursue through two further signings. Certainly, Spurs need more new blood. Even Rebrov's quality and creditable performances by Neil Sullivan and Ben Thatcher could not banish that unconvincing look of last season. Sol Campbell was frequently outmanoeuvred by David Johnson.

Tottenham stuttered until Richard Wright demonstrated his new habit of conceding penalties by pulling down a player, in this case Carr. Darren Anderton converted and 60 seconds later Carr himself drove inside the near post. fields.bodyText: A little more than two hours into the new season, George Graham hammered on in inimitable fashion about "the team ethic" and "sacrifices", beliefs that he insists his No11 wholeheartedly shares. For all that, Sergei Rebrov is patently first among equals. With his quickness and cleverness, the £11m Ukrainian helped Graham win this opening battle and, with it, the PR war in this post-Ginola era. Save for a brief mention in the manager's programme notes - "I felt that the time was right for David to move on" - the Frenchman's name remained unspoken. Enter Rebrov instead, a small striker almost lost amid the larger physiques of his new team-mates. You wondered again how he came to be here. Surely it was not the challenge of the likes of Ipswich Town that drew him to north London. Nor surely the man-mountains Hermann Hreidarsson and Titus Bramble in the visitors' defence, who seemed to glower down on the newcomer. Ninety minutes later another question arose: Rebrov can read the game, but can Spurs read him? The rampaging Stephen Carr could, on one occasion streaming on to the Ukrainian's pass to hit Tottenham's second goal. Two minutes earlier came a delicious foretaste: a sudden shot, delivered by Rebrov with the outside of his right foot from 20 yards, that landed on the crossbar. Graham eagerly seized upon that startling moment as "showing the kind of class he's got". The manager conceded that Rebrov could have had a hat-trick - once, with time to spare, he badly miscued a volley - but it seemed churlish to pursue this. As Graham insisted: "He's a team player." And, after all, Spurs had fought back to beat a team who asked some awkward questions. Ultimately the killing goal came from Les Ferdinand's almost forgotten locker of powerful headers. But given the fragility of Ipswich's defence, it was difficult to assess whether Spurs can fulfil their manager's aim of rising from 10th position to "round about the top six, or in the top six". That seems a modest target for Spurs fans weaned on grander traditions. Rebrov, Graham suggests, is a symbol of the ambition he intends to pursue through two further signings. Certainly, Spurs need more new blood. Even Rebrov's quality and creditable performances by Neil Sullivan and Ben Thatcher could not banish that unconvincing look of last season. fields.headline: Savage and desperate stuff
fields.trailText: Leicester 0 - 0 Aston Villa
fields.body:
When these sides met in last year's Worthington Cup, rival fans chanted "Boring, boring" at each other. On Saturday they did not. That cup semi-final must have been bad. This was the cream of Midlands football. Already it tastes sour.

The match was full of good prospects - Peter Taylor's first game in charge of Leicester, Stan Collymore's return against the last club to misunderstand him, the predictable fitness of Neil Lennon (and Gerry Taggart) after withdrawal from Northern Ireland's midweek game, debuts for Villa by David Ginola and the Turk Alpay Ozalan, who sounds like a cure for depression; he could be useful.

Instead Robbie Savage seized the spotlight early, set the mood and soon they were all playing like savages. It was the law of the jungle with no clear path through and hacking the only way, desperate more than dirty. Only when the ball was with Paul Merson or Muzzy Izzet did there seem to be light. They consistently found space and team-mates but were often obliged to turn back for want of options from formations more 5-3-2 than 3-5-2.

Closing down was top priority, so Ginola got little look-in, a testy booking and only an hour to play with. The attacks were less of a lessness. Dion Dublin should have hit the target with two late headers over. Collymore and Ade Akinbiyi are short of understanding. But Akinbiyi disconcerted with his pace, first leading to a cross that Collymore met unconvincingly, later going clear and blasting David James into action.

James was last seen flapping the Cup to Chelsea at Wembley. Now he was clad in silver, which was fine for that save, embarrassingly eyecatching when he came for a cross that Collymore beat him to without the power to score. Collymore lacks match sharpness.

Taylor felt Villa's tougher pre-season, going out of the Intertoto Cup, showed; so he was "pleased with a point". He started last season, his first at Gillingham, with two defeats, then three draws, and ended it in promotion. But he needs Steve Guppy for skilled width.

Villa, too, need enlightenment. John Gregory received a driving ban last week. Chastened could turn to beleaguered if they do not show better against Chelsea and Liverpool. Though Gareth Southgate showed no lack of commitment, too many players in a squad from one to 40 (Matthew Ghent) failed to escape in the summer.

It all amounted to a joyless game, which paid no heed to the reminder from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents to "kill speed and reduce carnage". December's return match could aptly be sponsored by The Priory.

webTitle: Rangers driven on by lure of Europe

fields.headline: Rangers driven on by lure of Europe
fields.trailText: Rangers 4 - 1 Dunfermline
fields.body:
Scottish football feels stirring in its loins at the thought of a new European League involving Rangers and Celtic, and this affair at Ibrox hardly helped to quell the fever. A crowd of 48,000 traipsed along to watch Rangers dole out another domestic drubbing, but there must be increasing numbers among the diehards who yearn for something more competitive than this.

The dominance of Rangers, though tiresome to many, should still be kept in perspective. If Manchester United can win six of the last eight Premiership titles up for grabs, and teams in Spain, Portugal and Germany are all familiar with some form of subjugation, the state of the game in Scotland is obviously not unique. With Celtic having started with four wins out of four under Martin O'Neill, there is also evidence at least of a battle developing for the Premier League title.

Rangers, none the less, must crave for the group stages of the Champions League to begin. Their manager, Dick Advocaat, who would not be dwarfed by Sir Alex Ferguson in terms of his keen approach to every match, must know that games like these against local fodder are not the stuff of glory. Advocaat has been to World Cups leading Holland and had boisterous run-ins with Ruud Gullit. He is a man whose sense of the glamour of football looks well beyond Saturday's business.

Dunfermline are under the charge of Jimmy Calderwood, a gnarled Scot who has crossed swords with Advocaat before during a 15-year career as a player and manager in Holland. Thus far, any rash thoughts that Dutch sophistication might be imported with Calderwood and naturally rub off on Dunfermline have proved futile.

Like Advocaat, who has gone Dutch in importing players to such an extent that he has almost caused an immigration problem, Calderwood has also gone "home" to improve his team. Marco Ruitenbeek, his new goalkeeper, found shots, crosses and assorted missiles raining down on him, to the point where Rangers had scored three by the 29th minute through Jorg Albertz, Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Billy Dodds. Rod Wallace added a fourth with a leaping header after 48 minutes.

Dunfermline did manage one miraculous riposte amid all this - a glancing header from Stephen Boyle which crept beyond the unsuspecting Stefan Klos, a German goalkeeper whose £17,000-a-week salary wasn't exactly grafted for.

Advocaat, with an eye on Europe, repeated yesterday that he wishes to spend around £8m on a new striker. So far, he has made five attempts to prise a player to these shores, each invitation being met with a blunt response. One of these targets, the Belgian striker, Emile Mpenza, even said that he feared coarse Scottish defenders would start hacking him. The Scots, it appears, have an image problem.

 Two headed goals from Chris Sutton put Celtic on their way to a 4-2 win at Hearts as they maintained their impressive start to the season. Henrik Larsson and Lubomir Moravcik also scored.

fields.headline: Palace undimmed by draw
fields.trailText: C Palace 1 -1 QPR
fields.body:
When the administrator has been ever-present on the team sheet for 19 months and the existence of the club has been in the melting pot, then the loss of two home points does not register very high on the scale of potential calamity.

Crystal Palace allowed their London rivals back into this contest yesterday but nobody minded too much. They have a new owner promising to give supporters a team to be proud of again and the sun shines once more on Selhurst Park.

Of course Palace diehards have heard it all before, only two years before, when the path to glory stretched out in front of Mark Goldberg who made his millions in computers. Now it is Simon Jordan at the helm whose vast fortune derives from mobile phones. The world has changed a fair bit since Malcolm Allison, presented to the crowd at half-time, donned his fedora to win Palace's attention in the early 80s.

The sense of optimism was embraced by Alan Smith who said he preferred to remember the smart second-minute double save from his rookie goalkeeper Stuart Taylor rather than his rash attempt to gather a high cross that saw Clarke Carlisle head his first goal in Rangers colours.

That 65th-minute equaliser was no more than a fluent Rangers deserved. Clarke, a summer signing from Blackpool already compared to a raw Sol Campbell by Gerry Francis, could have had a hat-trick.

Nevertheless Smith, the returning Palace manager, was pleased with what he saw. "This club has had two years of uncertainty and I want to bring a bit of stability around the place," he said. "Stuart was upset by the goal but I'm not. I'll work with him on the training ground and make him better."

If Mikael Forssell, fatigued by his midweek exertions on behalf of Finland, had put away a glorious second-half opportunity there would have been celebrations at the end to go with the stilt walkers and the jugglers who before the start heralded this new dawn.

Forssell gave Palace the lead just before the interval though he knew little about it, Simon Rodger's firm drive deflecting in off his hip. To be fair to Forssell it was his powerful cross-shot that led to the confusion in the Rangers rearguard.

Forssell's miss followed a dynamic surge from Tommy Black, the former Arsenal youngster who was forced to take on more midfield responsibility when Jamie Pollock was carried off on a stretcher following a clash of heads.

fields.headline: Kachloul answers wake-up call
fields.trailText: Derby 2 - 2 Southampton
fields.body:
Hassan Kachloul could be forgiven for not knowing whether he is coming or going. Last week Southampton accepted an offer of £1.8m for the Moroccan left-winger. This week he is the toast of the south coast after turning down Ipswich and scoring both goals in Saints' season's opener. "They should have sold him," grumbled the Derby manager Jim Smith.

Kachloul unsurprisingly took the opposite view. "I did not ask for a move," he said. "I felt it was not right for me. I like it at Southampton and I don't want people to think I want to leave.

"It's not a case of us wanting to sell Hassan," insisted the Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle. "I'm on record as saying any player is available.

"We're a club that has to generate finances, sometimes from within the squad, but the lad politely turned them down because he can see things might be happening here."

Perhaps the threat to sell was clever man-management from Hoddle aimed at inducing some resolve into the arty African's game. Kachloul gave the impression of being more than motivated as he put Southampton 2-0 up after 22 minutes, both goals the result of sweeping moves down the right that had their German debutant Uwe Rösler at the heart of them, giving the visiting Saints fans an excuse for a rare chant of: "We are top of the league."

At that stage Derby, shorn of five first-teamers including Georgi Kinkladze and featuring four debutants, Danny Higginbotham, Bjorn Otto Bragstad, Con Blatsis and Simo Valakari, were still introducing themselves.

But in the 32nd minute they got back into the game with their first shot on goal, a 20-yard free-kick from Branko Strupar. Southampton's zest evaporated and four minutes after the interval the Derby substitute Deon Burton slid in to rescue a point.

For Smith, it was an improvement on last season's recurrent capitulations. "We have to take out of it the fact we came back and got a draw. If we'd had a full team out it could have been different but if we can battle through two away games there is a 10-day break and then we'll have our players back." Hoddle said bluntly: "It was a game we should have won."

Derby now go to Newcastle and Everton, Southampton welcome Coventry and Liverpool, and if both can continue in a similar vein then worries over relegation should be a thing of the past. The Derby supporter who had the simple word HOPE printed on the back of his replica shirt can think about changing it to EXPECTATION.

webTitle: Italian offers Jewell light in the dark

fields.headline: Italian offers Jewell light in the dark
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 2 - 3 Huddersfield
fields.body:
If Paul Jewell needed confirmation of the scale of the task confronting him at Hillsborough, this defeat at the hands of their near neighbours Huddersfield offered it in spades. A hard-earned draw at Wolves last week had raised hopes that last season's half-hearted capitulations were a thing of the past but the opening 40 minutes of this match swiftly consigned such thoughts to the pending tray.

Wednesday were back in their familiar role as architects of their own misfortune, presenting goals to Martin Smith, twice, and Kevin Gallen through a combination of negligible concentration and bad defending.

Jewell's half-time withdrawal of Wim Jonk and Gilles de Bilde offered a hint as to where the manager felt the problems lay and it took the introduction of an Italian teenager, Michele di Piedi, to introduce a sense of willingness to the side.

Di Piedi cut an unlikely figure up front, long hair flapping, socks rolled down, happily chasing causes long lost. It was a reflection of the commitment-free diet fed to the Hillsborough crowd that the biggest cheer of the afternoon was reserved for the 19-year-old's hopeful charge into midfield to win a nothing ball with a desperate lunge.

Jewell recognised the value of the former Perugia youngster's contribution saying: "Michele puts his heart and sole into his job and wants to be a Sheffield Wednesday player. If you have enough people like that you are in with half a chance."

Di Piedi's spirit was contagious and Wednesday could have earned a point if Ashley Westwood had not hit a post from just two yards. That would have been harsh on Huddersfield who, despite the possible frailty of their squad, turned in a display of potency and guile.

webTitle: Heskey has Hutchings quoting losing lines

fields.headline: Heskey has Hutchings quoting losing lines
fields.standfirst: Fine-tuning needed before Houllier's side can explode
fields.trailText: Liverpool 1 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
Chris Hutchings's jaunt around the managerial learning curve will, no doubt, be swift and torturous and yet even if journey's end should ultimately come to represent nothing more edifying than a handsome severance cheque it does seem probable he will quite enjoy the experience.

Small, unassuming and with the finely-chiselled features and slicked-back hair of an eighties New Romantic pop icon, the new manager of Bradford City looked very much at home at Anfield on Saturday evening, explaining away defeat with a dash of engaging realism.

In truth, Hutchings is likely be called upon to repeat the speech on countless occasions over the next nine months for while his team is crammed full of game triers who will, occasionally, overturn the apple-cart, he will, eventually be forced to concede that long gone are the days when ceaseless endeavour was the bedrock upon which success was built.

"The boys did very well but the boys are very disappointed with the result," said Hutchings afterwards, possibly attempting to push those with whom he was sharing a first audience towards the conclusion that here was a man who had already mastered the art of the managerial cliche.

This was hardly the grand flourish, the sweeping, spectacle which the dawning of a new season demanded but with Liverpool - initially at least - cautious and Bradford keeping most of their men behind the ball, we were, perhaps, fortunate to witness even one goal.

It was a gem, though, Emile Heskey turning and sprinting forward before unleashing a fabulous, rising drive which found its target long, long before the Bradford goalkeeper Matthew Clarke had raised a paw in mock defiance.

Heskey's goal was well timed, for it came along at the precise moment he seemed to be attempting to place still more daylight between himself and full acceptance at a club where he is still viewed with some suspicion. If the goal shone a beacon of light in the direction of the big lad's true potential it was hardly sufficient to erase the memory of his dismal contribution up to that point.

His manager, Gérard Houllier, is fully aware of the continuing problems Heskey is facing as he seeks to justify an inflated price-tag.

"He is young and he needs our support," said the Frenchman with almost paternal affection. "We will back him and we will support him. He has many assets - the problem being he doesn't always choose to use them to the full."

It would be churlish to be too critical of either side for both have much fine-tuning to complete after a summer of feverish activity in the transfer market.

Liverpool still resemble a quality, potentially exhilarating, side waiting to happen but they have many admirable qualities and their appeal has not been diluted by the arrival of luminaries like Gary McAllister, Markus Babbel and Nick Barmby.

They were not at their best on Saturday but stage-fright afflicts the bravest of hearts and in the early period, before the Ibiza tans have faded, winning really is all that matters.

Bradford's football was orderly but it lacked the devilment to trouble a Liverpool defence which was draped like a comfort blanket over the twin peaks of Sami Hyypia and Stéphane Henchoz.

"We played really well in the first half but then tended to defend far too deep," said Hutchings. Defending deep could well prove to be a blessing tomorrow night when Chelsea visit Valley Parade.

There is not a soul in the nation who doesn't wish Bradford well but, whether they like it or not, their grim fight for survival is already well underway.

Liverpool's Czech Republic international midfielder Patrik Berger could be sidelined for up to two months after damaging lateral knee ligaments during Saturday's game.

It would be churlish to be too critical of either side for both have much fine-tuning to complete after a summer of feverish activity in the transfer market. Liverpool still resemble a quality, potentially exhilarating, side waiting to happen but they have many admirable qualities and their appeal has not been diluted by the arrival of luminaries like Gary McAllister, Markus Babbel and Nick Barmby. They were not at their best on Saturday but stage-fright afflicts the bravest of hearts and in the early period, before the Ibiza tans have faded, winning really is all that matters. Bradford's football was orderly but it lacked the devilment to trouble a Liverpool defence which was draped like a comfort blanket over the twin peaks of Sami Hyypia and Stéphane Henchoz. "We played really well in the first half but then tended to defend far too deep," said Hutchings. Defending deep could well prove to be a blessing tomorrow night when Chelsea visit Valley Parade. There is not a soul in the nation who doesn't wish Bradford well but, whether they like it or not, their grim fight for survival is already well underway. Liverpool's Czech Republic international midfielder Patrik Berger could be sidelined for up to two months after damaging lateral knee ligaments during Saturday's game.

webTitle: Cracks show as Arsenal suffer from tunnel vision

fields.headline: Cracks show as Arsenal suffer from tunnel vision
fields.standfirst: Wenger's day of frustration capped by early exit as Vieira gets physical
fields.trailText: Sunderland 1 - 0 Arsenal
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger could not believe his eyes. "If Sunderland can win games after being dominated like that they will win the championship," he said.

If Arsenal fail to be more incisive and Patrick Vieira fails to control his frustration there is as much chance of the title coming to Highbury as there is of "Nasty" Nick Bateman becoming prime minister.

Had Arsenal won by three goals few could have argued. Yet for all the visitors' superiority, there were signs of vulnerability as well. And not just in poor finishing which suggested several players, notably Ray Parlour, spent the summer studying the video "Chris Sutton: the Chelsea Year".

The ponytailed David Seaman proved he is no Samson by gifting Niall Quinn the decisive goal, while Vieira's swipe at Darren Williams in the final minute confirmed his monumental talent continues to be undermined by his temperament. It provided the fifth red card of his Arsenal career and the 30th of Wenger's time at Highbury.

Of course the closer Vieira keeps to Roy Keane in the disciplinary points table the less likely Arsenal are to keep pace with Manchester United in the Premiership. With Emmanuel Petit gone, Vieira is more than ever the fulcrum of his team's midfield. In his absence, probably for three matches, Wenger will most likely pair Parlour with Gilles Grimandi. After the Petit-Vieira axis that lacks a certain je ne sais quoi .

Throughout the first half in particular, Vieira played with an unparalleled authority. Yet the 24-year-old's reaction to Williams' fouling hinted that Sunderland's fierce, niggling approach could bear fruit for others against Arsenal.

"People pay to watch football not to see people break attacks down," Wenger said angrily. "We tried to go forward and were repeatedly held back. Referees have a responsibility to get that out of the game. Patrick has tried to play football and some others have not. In the end he is sent off for a bad reaction. It's unbelievable."

Sunderland's manager Peter Reid felt Vieira was "desperately unlucky" to go, yet when will the Frenchman curb his tendency to seek retribution when he feels unprotected by officials? His forearm swipe at Williams may have been, in Wenger's words, a "natural reaction" to having his shirt tugged but it was not the right one. That it was born of frustration rather than malice was apparently a compliment to Sunderland.

"You've got to get compact and you've got to get in people's faces," Williams said. "If you give the big teams time they can pass it forever, and they'll get people forward and break you down. You can end up losing by a lot of goals.

"Last season away from home we respected Arsenal too much and sat off a bit [and were beaten 4-1]. The manager and [his assistant] Bobby Saxton were saying we had to get up against them."

Williams, not surprisingly, rebuffed Wenger's accusation that he tried to get Vieira sent off. The Arsenal manager claimed the referee Steve Dunn had been "very naive", though those words seemed more applicable to Vieira. Raise an arm to an opponent's face and you can have few complaints at being sent off. Vieira's more controlled work since his spat and spit at West Ham last October has been undone.

Long before Vieira's dismissal Arsenal should have had the game won. Poor finishing and impressive keeping by Thomas Sorensen and his second-half replacement Jurgen Macho denied them.

Although Wenger professed himself happy with the performance, he must be worried by Seaman's decline. Called on for almost the only time after 53 minutes the 36-year-old failed to claim Michael Gray's deep left-wing cross, allowing Quinn to head in.

Seaman's increasing fallibility, coupled with the fact that Tony Adams cannot be expected to play every match, does not bode well. Arsenal's new signings Robert Pires and Lauren began on the bench, hinting that they will need time to settle in. And although Gilles Grimandi performed tidily he offers neither the driving force nor the vision of Petit.

Grimandi, Parlour and Fredrik Ljungberg are doubtful for tonight's visit of Liverpool but Wenger might settle for being outplayed and winning at Highbury.

webTitle: Boksic catches the eye on new catwalk

fields.headline: Boksic catches the eye on new catwalk
fields.trailText: Coventry 1 - 3 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Stands the clock at 10 to 3? And is that a supermodel in row B? Thanks to global warming, exotic creatures are increasingly to be seen far from their traditional habitats. Not only that, they appear quite comfortable at latitudes that were once assumed to be hostile to them.

Adriana Sklenarikova, Christian Karembeu's supermodel wife, did not make it here on Saturday but Alen Boksic already looks right at home in the Premiership. He has had an undistinguished time of it recently - the season before last he did not actually play a complete game for Lazio or Croatia - but he is still only 30 and appears little debilitated.

On his Middlesbrough debut he laid on the first goal, scored the other two and should have been allowed a third. He has strength and pace and application, supposedly the staples of the English game, as well as intelligence, technical ability and a relentless eye for counter-attacking opportunities. Maybe he should have been over here all along.

And this is not even the complete Boksic. The striker had hardly begun training with Lazio, because the Serie A season does not start until October. What will he be able to do when he is match fit? "I will be an excited manager," said Bryan Robson, "if he gets better than that."

Robson said that he had been "trying to bring in real quality players" and on the evidence of this match he has had some success. Joseph-Desire Job has less experience than Boksic but showed a maturing appreciation of an unusual role, attacking wide on the right, and took his goal splendidly, getting on the wrong side of Marcus Hall and deftly placing his header past Magnus Hedman. And Karembeu, who is Real quality, looked outstanding in the hostile confines of an English midfield, even if he appears to be duplicating Paul Ince's work.

Though Coventry ran the middle half-hour of the game, they have some catching up to do. They have lost their player of the season and their two leading scorers. In addition, Mustapha Hadji, Stephen Froggatt and Tomas Gustafsson are out injured and others have suffered an interrupted pre-season. Gordon Strachan's legendary equanimity was further tested 20 minutes from the end when David Thompson was sent off for a tackle on Ince that won the ball.

Cheap red cards are an occupational hazard these days, along with over friendly supermodels. Karembeu met his on an aeroplane. There is hardly a check-in counter queue that is not decorated by the odd supermodel and her half-ton of Gucci luggage.

Highfield Road, though, is resisting. At the end of this game steely-eyed stewards ringed the pitch, just in case Cindy Crawford had come for Colin Hendry.

fields.headline: Resurrection game
fields.standfirst: Interactive versions of tired gameshows are breathing new life into old favourites - and proving that TV can work on the web. By David Teather
fields.trailText: Interactive versions of tired gameshows are breathing new life into old favourites - and proving that TV can work on the web.
fields.body:
Catchphrase, the long-running ITV gameshow, could hardly be described as cutting-edge television. A badly drawn cartoon of a horse that has seen better days appears with "for sale" written over its head. The answer to this conundrum? Flogging a dead horse - and so it goes on for 30 frankly excruciating minutes.

The programme, produced by Carlton's Action Time, is, however, at the vanguard of TV's attempt to engage with new technology. Catchphrase is one of a growing number of gameshows to produce faithful online versions which are proving increasingly popular and allow fans to play each other at any time of the day.

The marketing men call it brand extension and enthuse about the cross-promotion opportunities. In the US, Uproar.com, which features a series of games including Family Feud (known here as the less adversarial Family Fortunes) and 100%, is one of the top 30 sites and among the top 10 "stickiest".

While other TV formats such as drama or sitcom are struggling to grapple with what opportunities the internet or interactivity might present, the humble gameshow looks as though it could have been invented with the web in mind.

But online versions of existing games are only the beginning. As digital technology becomes more widespread, viewers will be able to play along with contestants while watching the programme on TV.

The gameshow genre, which had already been given a dramatic shot in the arm by Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, looks set to have its place in the schedules cemented and it is not only the likes of Millionaire or the "psycho" formats inspired by Big Brother that stand to benefit. Interactivity and online versions could breathe new life into formats that have been on air for years.

"This is a very exciting time," says Stephen Leahy, joint managing director at Action Time and a veteran of gameshows dating back to the Krypton Factor. "I've been in gameshows for 25 years and they've suddenly become this modern currency instead of being the forgotten bit in the schedule. Millionaire has obviously had an effect, but it is also because gameshows are ahead of what other types of TV formats can do with interactivity."

Pearson, the UK-based media company was sufficiently convinced by the potential to take an 11% stake in Uproar in return for licensing some of its most popular gameshows to the site. Pearson owns the rights to a raft of formats including The Price is Right, the aforementioned Family Feud, 100% and Matchgame, screened in this country as Blankety Blank.

The online versions already up and running are made to replicate the TV experience as closely as possible using the same graphics, rules and sound effects. Prizes on offer range from cash to Amazon vouchers, widescreen TVs and telescopes.

Martin Trickey, entertainment producer at Uproar, describes the phenomenon as "the yelling at the TV screen thing. You want simple games that people are familiar with and ones that people get involved in".

Pearson hopes to launch an online version of The Price is Right towards the end of the year but, alive to the opportunity, is for the first time developing the game in-house as well as bringing the Uproar games to the UK site.

A typical 15-minute game will be broken by a commercial break which Catherine Mackay, president of Pearson TV Enterprises, optimistically says helps to complete the experience that you are playing in the gameshow on TV: "You are getting 3,000 people playing Family Feud online at any one time which says that gameshows work in that medium. Our online business looks as though it will be profitable in its first full year and these are all incremental revenues. We have 65 gameshow formats, so there is clearly a big opportunity here."

The real prize for producers and the TV networks, though, will be the adoption of digital services by cable and satellite broadcasters which will allow people to play along. "Gameshows will be a frontrunner in broadband," says Leahy.

Two Way TV, which has pioneered the development of interactive technology, conducted gameshow trials using an analogue set-top box over a 12-month period in Birmingham in 1997. Deals were struck with all the major channels and interactive versions were produced of shows including University Challenge, Fifteen to One, Wheel of Fortune and Countdown.

The aim again is to replicate the on-screen experience for the viewer playing along. You would either be able to play the rest of the country or simply the people in your living room, or the contestants on screen.

Marjorie Curtis, head of marketing at Two Way TV, says the introduction of interactivity broadened the type of viewers tuning in during the trials. It seems a reasonable point. The chances are you've never appeared on a TV gameshow. When was the last time you can remember anyone who actually works in the media, for example, putting their wits on public display for Who Wants to be a Millionaire? or waving to the camera as he or she disappeared round the corner on Blankety Blank?

"Who would want to appear on one of those shows?" says Curtis. "But that doesn't mean you don't sit there thinking 'I knew that, the money should be mine.'"

Two Way TV claims that during the trials, viewing figures for the likes of University Challenge and Fifteen to One doubled with interactivity, while Play Your Cards Right went from 17% to just under 30% audience share. Cable company NTL recently took a 48% stake in the business and it has contracts in place to develop interactive facilities for both NTL and rival Telewest. Viewers should be able to play along with the games within six months.

Two Way TV announced a number of deals, including one with Pearson which will add an interactive element to Fifteen to One, Family Fortunes, 100%, Strike It Lucky and Whittle.

Viewers' willingness to play a behind the scenes part in gameshows has been demonstrated to rich effect by Big Brother which has invited people to vote contestants out and used the internet to provide a multi-layering effect.

The latest in the UK is The People Versus which invites viewers to set the questions. Action Time has begun shooting the pilot of a show called Bankraid where viewers can get the profile of three potential contestants on the internet the previous day and then vote online who should take part.

Millionaire has already proved that the gameshow format can become "event TV" again - not really the case since Anthea twirled for the last time. The ability to play along could mean that the effect will bleed out into less blockbusting shows.

"The fireside may not be back but you will get families plonked on the sofa playing these games together," says Leahy.

webTitle: How Nasty Nick united two worlds

fields.headline: How Nasty Nick united two worlds
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Angry bosses around the country, including other TV channels, called Channel 4, pleading with it to turn off the webcams because none of their staff was doing any work.
fields.body:
People use all sorts of strategies to avoid working in August. Some go on holiday. Others are regularly "ill" on sunny workdays.

But last Thursday, those who did drag themselves into work found another excuse for inactivity: Nasty Nick's looming departure from Big Brother. It was mayhem. Nobody did any work that day. Everyone was watching the internet.

Angry bosses around the country, including other TV channels, called Channel 4, pleading with it to turn off the webcams because none of their staff was doing any work. By anyone's standards, it was a mass-media experience.

In the early hours of that morning, there hadn't been as many viewers, but the all-night addicts had been fuming. The webcams had been turned off at a crucial moment. The news on the wires was that the Big Brother website had been shut down deliberately by Channel 4 at around 1am - and it spread faster than a Midwest fire as the late-night nerds hit the chatrooms.

Was it a sinister move on Channel 4's part? Had the website really been shut down because there was the chance of a violent confrontation between two members of the house? What were the editorial guidelines? Was the open network of the internet being censored?

The stories proved to be true - Channel 4 had pulled the plug. An overzealous night editor had turned off the webcams when it looked as if a fight was impending. Blimey, how awful, a fist fight at three o'clock in the morning. There are shows on Channel 4 such as South Park that don't exactly go easy on the violence. Why should the web suffer stricter editorial guidelines than TV?

Of course it shouldn't and, to Channel 4's credit, it admitted it had made a mistake. It had been too cautious. This was a timely reminder that the path to TV and internet convergence will not be seamless. Mistakes will be made.

And while we're at it, we'll hold our hands up as well, as the people who built the Big Brother website. Everyone involved in this extra-ordinary project has had to adapt one way or another. No amount of planning could have prepared us for the wave of Big Brother hysteria that has held the country in its grip. Managing what is essentially a live event for 64 days has pushed both technical and editorial teams to the limit.

After last Thursday, nobody can be in any doubt. In our offices there were people crowded around computer monitors watching events unfold. We were not alone. Surely this was broadcast history?

Parallel broadcasting is the latest buzzword, but there was little evidence of it before Big Brother. True integration is next - and broadband technology will make it a reality.

But if the convergence between the internet and TV isn't to become a collision, these media need to work together. Being big on the internet doesn't necessarily mean that TV viewing figures will decline. Viral marketing? Bollocks. Call it good old-fashioned word of mouth. Internet page impressions went through the roof and boosted, not hindered, the TV audience that night. If the content is compelling enough and production teams plan well, the internet and TV can feed each other. It is the viewer who wins.

The internet is here, officially confirmed by those wired office workers on that warm day in August. It has the capability to change everything, especially when it comes to video streaming - and the big new media players are circling in an attempt to inure us to video-computers.

Real Networks has seen 500,000 UK users download its software in order to watch Big Brother on the web. It's big business and it's catching on quickly. Big Brother is now a brand. And brands sell.

I'd never before downloaded software that showed me pictures on my computer. Big Brother changed that. I had to download Real Player 7 to see pictures from the house. I obviously was not the only one.

It was weird at first. I was used to logging on to the BBC's website and never listening or watching to any of the audio or video stories. It's a new world now. I'm getting used to it. I want to watch my computer and, in the future, a mobile device. I don't want to have to set the video. I want it now, I want it moving and if I feel like watching it again, I want to be able to.

Next season, it will be something new. The summer of Big Brother will be history. The next entertainment format will knock us for six again. There's no doubt about that. Whether it will be "only a game show" is up to us.

But when Nick, Mel and the rest of the Big Brother posse have moved out of the limelight, they will have left behind something more lasting than mere skul-duggery. They were part of a much larger experiment. They were part of the future of broadcasting.

Paul Munford is the media communications manager of Victoria Real, the company that designed and built the Big Brother website.

By anyone's standards, it was a mass-media experience. In the early hours of that morning, there hadn't been as many viewers, but the all-night addicts had been fuming. The webcams had been turned off at a crucial moment. The news on the wires was that the Big Brother website had been shut down deliberately by Channel 4 at around 1am - and it spread faster than a Midwest fire as the late-night nerds hit the chatrooms. Was it a sinister move on Channel 4's part? Had the website really been shut down because there was the chance of a violent confrontation between two members of the house? What were the editorial guidelines? Was the open network of the internet being censored? The stories proved to be true - Channel 4 had pulled the plug. An overzealous night editor had turned off the webcams when it looked as if a fight was impending. Blimey, how awful, a fist fight at three o'clock in the morning. There are shows on Channel 4 such as South Park that don't exactly go easy on the violence. Why should the web suffer stricter editorial guidelines than TV? Of course it shouldn't and, to Channel 4's credit, it admitted it had made a mistake. It had been too cautious. This was a timely reminder that the path to TV and internet convergence will not be seamless. Mistakes will be made. And while we're at it, we'll hold our hands up as well, as the people who built the Big Brother website. Everyone involved in this extra-ordinary project has had to adapt one way or another. No amount of planning could have prepared us for the wave of Big Brother hysteria that has held the country in its grip. Managing what is essentially a live event for 64 days has pushed both technical and editorial teams to the limit. After last Thursday, nobody can be in any doubt. In our offices there were people crowded around computer monitors watching events unfold. We were not alone. Surely this was broadcast history? Parallel broadcasting is the latest buzzword, but there was little evidence of it before Big Brother. True integration is next - and broadband technology will make it a reality. But if the convergence between the internet and TV isn't to become a collision, these media need to work together. Being big on the internet doesn't necessarily mean that TV viewing figures will decline. Viral marketing? Bollocks. Call it good old-fashioned word of mouth. Internet page impressions went through the roof and boosted, not hindered, the TV audience that night. If the content is compelling enough and production teams plan well, the internet and TV can feed each other. It is the viewer who wins. The internet is here, officially confirmed by those wired office workers on that warm day in August. It has the capability to change everything, especially when it comes to video streaming - and the big new media players are circling in an attempt to inure us to video-computers. Real Networks has seen 500,000 UK users download its software in order to watch Big Brother on the web. It's big business and it's catching on quickly. Big Brother is now a brand. And brands sell. I'd never before downloaded software that showed me pictures on my computer. Big Brother changed that. I had to download Real Player 7 to see pictures from the house. I obviously was not the only one. It was weird at first. I was used to logging on to the BBC's website and never listening or watching to any of the audio or video stories. It's a new world now. I'm getting used to it. I want to watch my computer and, in the future, a mobile device. I don't want to have to set the video. I want it now, I want it moving and if I feel like watching it again, I want to be able to. Next season, it will be something new. The summer of Big Brother will be history. The next entertainment format will knock us for six again. There's no doubt about that. Whether it will be "only a game show" is up to us. But when Nick, Mel and the rest of the Big Brother posse have moved out of the limelight, they will have left behind something more lasting than mere skul-duggery. They were part of a much larger experiment. They were part of the future of broadcasting. Paul Munford is the media communications manager of Victoria Real, the company that designed and built the Big Brother website.

fields.headline: Caribbean on hurricane alert
fields.standfirst: Simon Rogers and Liza Ramrayka report from Saint Francois, Guadeloupe, on the tropical storm Debby which is threatening to turn into a category-one hurricane
fields.trailText: Simon Rogers and Liza Ramrayka report from Saint Francois, Guadeloupe on the tropical storm Debby which is threatening to turn into a category-one hurricane
fields.body:
Hurricane season started in Guadeloupe at 4am, Caribbean time, when the power went off. The hotel was plunged into darkness and the air conditioning died. Outside, thunder roared and lightning lit up the main tourist beach at Saint Francois.

By late morning, the weather became calm but blustery - however, torrential rain and high winds are just the first inklings of tropical storm Debby, presently heading across the Atlantic over the northern leeward islands.

At the moment, it is still defined as a tropical storm, with winds of 50mph. A tropical storm watch has been issued in popular holiday spots like Guadeloupe, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and Antigua.

But by tonight, it is expected to harden into a category-one hurricane, the lowest of its kind with winds expected to reach 95mph. The US national hurricane centre in Miami has issued a hurricane watch for Puerto Rico and several of the Dutch Caribbean islands and the US Virgin islands. It may even reach the east coast of the US.

Here in the heart of the French Caribbean, life continues in its normal relaxed way, despite sporadic radio warnings to 'evacuate anything not fixed to the ground' and to 'remove external aerials from all roofs'.

Tourists still line up for diving expeditions and trips to nearby islands. The souvenir shops and pavement cafes around the marina at Saint Francois are still busy, despite the fact the storm is expected to hit the island within hours.

'We get this every year, at this time,' says Anne Hochart, owner of l'@robas cyber cafe in Saint Francois. 'You can't be complacent, but we're not really panicking'.

Guadeloupe has a history of natural disasters - in 1989, Hurricane Hugo devastated large parts of the island, including the tourist resort of Saint-Anne on the south coast. In 1976, 70,000 people were evacuated from the area around La Soufriere, the 1467m volcano which threatened to erupt on the western Basse Terre side of the island.

Debby is the fourth tropical storm of the Atlantic season this year. Hurricane Alberto is the longest lived August tropical storm on record, still spiralling away in the mid-Atlantic after 68 warnings.

webTitle: Easy ways to reinvent our industry

fields.headline: Easy ways to reinvent our industry
fields.standfirst:
Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw a sketch of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is given a "reality check" by former mandarin Sir Peter Kemp. His critiques appear on our website. Today we look at trade and industry

Special report: road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw a sketch of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is given a "reality check" by former mandarin Sir Peter Kemp. His critiques appear on our website. Today we look at trade and industry
fields.body:
Labour should rebrand the DTI, making it not the Department of Trade and Industry but the Department for Technology and the Internet. That would send an instant, important message about its crucial role in the information revolution. For if the DTI had no other task than to bully companies and public sector bodies into reinventing their businesses to meet the needs of the internet age, then it would earn its budget 10 times over.

After all, Britain's future economic growth will depend on the speed with which we embrace the new technologies.

The beauty of it is that it won't cost money. The DTI is already a low spender. Expenditure this year (which was only £3.7bn) is set to grow by 23%, but that's because of spending on the detritus of the old economy - liabilities arising from the nuclear power and coal industries. The really important things the department can do for the new economy are not about spending money, but about structure and competition. The DTI is potentially more powerful than it ever was in its "interventionist" period under the last Labour administration because of its ability to set the parameters within which the new economy operates.

Take the auction of segments of the radio spectrum for the "third generation" of mobile phones, which raised £22.5bn. Irrespective of whether you think this is a fiscal coup or a recipe for unaffordable phones, it does show the enormous power the DTI still wields.

The department also played a leading role in the European-wide adoption of GSM (global system for mobile communications) as the standard for the current generation of mobile phones. The move attracted virtually no publicity at the time - nothing is more boring than a story about standardisation - yet the creation of this common European system is the single biggest reason why Europe now leads the world in mobile phones.

Television

Labour should propose two policies of comparable importance. First, pull the plug on analogue television as soon as possible. Eventually all televisions will be digital offering better definition, internet access, email, interactive sport, home shopping and, maybe the final marriage of the computer terminal and the television set. Remember, countries that switch over en masse to digital earliest, will have "first mover" advantage to develop products and services to sell to the world.

The only serious argument against an early switch off - that poor people won't be able to afford the cost - is potent but can be solved by subsidising adoption of digital television for the poor out of the money that will be raised from auctioning off the analogue spectrum released by the switch to digital.

Second, Labour should insist that British Telecom's monopoly of the "local loop", the last mile from the exchange to your home, is opened up immediately and affordably to competitors offering broadband access. The aim is to get broadband (that is, high speed links capable of two-way video transmission) to as many homes as possible in the shortest time.

This argument has been going on for more than 15 years. The Conservatives refused BT's offer to bring broadband to homes in exchange for being allowed to broadcast entertainment (like profitable video on demand) because it would have undermined the government's encouragement of cable companies to set up in competition with BT. It didn't occur to ministers that if high-capacity fibre optics had been laid to every home as "common carriers", there would have been no need to dig up the roads for cable.

BT has been resisting government sponsored incursions into its lucrative monopoly of the local loop so as to protect its revenues. The government should take BT on, in order to get broadband everywhere as soon as possible - so that consumers can enjoy it and companies can develop products on the back of it to sell on the world markets.

Labour should do this in conjunction with an all-out effort by the DTI, as a kind of free management consultancy, to make sure that companies, especially smaller ones, hook their businesses on to the internet. The prime minister has already made a bold promise of Britain becoming the best place in the world for e-commerce but the government itself is not setting the lead. Whitehall websites, though improving, lack professionalism. And when it comes to a sensitive issue like the government's power to monitor email through the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, the DTI has been only too happy to pass the buck to the Home Office. Britain will, therefore, have one of the most draconian regimes in the world.

Ireland

The regulatory situation in the UK could lead companies to set up in Ireland where, deliberately, there is a regime that's friendly to industry, and where email communications between companies are more secure. This is yet another example of the enormous power government wields even when it isn't spending anything. Labour should promise, for business as well as civil libertarian reasons, to repeal the RIP act.

This principle also applies to the DTI's ongoing role in the "old economy". The single most important thing it could and should do costs nothing, yet it has always been shirked. The DTI should be the unashamed public advocate of a competitive exchange rate for industry. That means campaigning for a rate up to 20% lower than it is now. If it had done this before, it could have avoided a worsening trade deficit, the intense profits squeeze on exporters, and the crises in the motor, textile, coal and steel industries.

It is absurd that the DTI has acquiesced in a surcharge on the industry it is supposed to be sponsoring. It is time the DTI changed from being a department of industry to a department for industry. Labour should lead that switch.

However, there are still several areas where extra money must be spent. Not in the form of old-style subsidies but as seed corn. As we discuss elsewhere in the manifesto, one is on an increase in the science budget - with the budget rising from £1.6bn this year to £2.2bn in 2003/4, and helped by windfalls from the Wellcome Trust, scientists are starting to feel wanted again, but their expectations have been dimmed by the neglect of the past two decades. The completion of the genome project has added a new urgency to the task of converting good ideas from the lab into world-class products in industry. And if Britain is to profit from the explosive growth expected in the biotech industries, then pump-priming money must be made available - maybe as incentives for venture capital companies - to convert Britain's expertise into the raw material for economic growth in the 21st century.

The same goes for alternative energy resources such as wind and solar power, the forgotten parts of the DTI's portfolio. It is barmy, the department having to spend tens of millions on the liabilities created by the rapid decline of coal and nuclear power while not being able to spend greatly increased resources on environmentally clean alternative resources.

It wouldn't cost much to bridge the gap between research on clean renewables, and the market place. It would be a long-term investment with an assured future return and with hardly any serious implications for inflation. It would barely make a pinprick on the £22.5bn the DTI has already raised for the Treasury this year from the radio spectrum auction. It is difficult to think of money that would be better spent.

Pledges

1. Rebrand the DTI as the Department for Technology and the Internet

2. Campaign for a lower exchange rate

3. Pull the plug on analogue television now

4. Make the DTI a free consultancy for smaller companies

5. Spend money on solar and wind power - to turn scientific discoveries into successful companies
