fields.headline: Week one: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Our punters made their bets on Friday to mixed success
fields.trailText: Paul MacInnes: £5 on 0 or 1 goals in Leicester v Aston Villa (9/4)
fields.body:
Paul MacInnes: £5 on 0 or 1 goals in Leicester v Aston Villa (9/4)

I quite like this bet. Total goals is a statistically based market; the odds compilers have an initial template of prices based on results over several seasons which they adjust slightly upwards and downwards depending on the individual circumstances of the match then add on their 11% profit margin.

Sometimes they fail to adjust the prices enough one way and there is value to be had but, because a punter has to overcome the built-in profit margin as well, these occasions are likely to be few and far between.

The first game of a season between two teams with no major changes in defence over the summer could conceivably be expected to be low scoring. And as the Blue Square prices for this match were pretty much standard a bet could conceivably have been in order.

Mr MacInnes' self-justification I'm not quite so sure about - I'm not convinced Peter Taylor would want to start his tenure with a reputation for negative football and in David Ginola Villa surely have guile personified (although after that dive I'm not so sure anymore).

But my major quibble with the bet would be whether there wasn't much better value to be had in backing 0-0 at 8/1 (or rather No Goalscorer at the same price as that way if one side wins 1-0 through an own goal you still collect).

Its all very well "allowing for the odd fluke goal", as Mr MacInnes said, but in the long term this could cost you money. But a winner is a winner, so plaudits to him.

Scott Murray: £5 on a line of three draws: Charlton v Manchester City (9/4); Derby v Southampton (9/4); Sunderland v Arsenal (9/4)

"Someone's always going to let you down on the first day of the season," wrote Mr Murray... so why not do a treble just to make sure.

If you stick to singles some selections are allowed to let you down as long as enough others don't; three singles on Mr Murray's selections would have resulted in a small profit.

Bookies love multiples, absolutely love 'em. More lovely profit margin, profit margin cubed. I'm sure we all know the temptation to go for the big hit and of course if all three of Mr Murray's selections had come in he would have made a good few quid, but generally we must resist this temptation. Remember it's a marathon not a sprint, we can be choosy, very choosy, and the more choosy we are the healthier the bank balance at the end of the season.

Anyway, I'm far from convinced that there is much of a future in backing draws, it seems a little too random to me. Unless I believe a game will be goalless, in which case I'll back no goalscorer, I'd much rather save my money for another day. It's easier and safer spotting underestimated or overestimated teams than it is spotting draws.

Sean Ingle: 4 x £1.50 trebles and £1 accumulator: Middlesbrough to beat Coventry (2/1), Leeds to draw with Everton (12/5), Blackburn to beat Crewe 4/5 and Sunderland to beat Arsenal (10/11)

Multiples are the bookies' friend and the punters' enemy. I don't disagree with Mr Ingle's sentiment "be cautious early" but on the other hand early season matches present an opportunity: once formlines become clearer bookmakers' mistakes become fewer.

Mr Ingle rightly spotted the value being offered about Middlesbrough. Coventry are in disarray having lost several of their better players, and ripe for opposing in the early season. While Middlesbrough, as usual, have spent fortunes in the close season, and as usual look like getting off to a flying start before the wheels come off and they settle for yet another disappointing season under the worst manager in English footballing history.

Mr Ingle got off to a good start but of course he ruined all the good work by picking three duffers to go with Middlesbrough. His reading of the Leeds game I can not agree with. Though Leeds did have injury worries they were playing Everton, who have all the same problems as Coventry only to the power ten. Everton are in for a tough season and I expect them to get off to an extremely sluggish start. Besides don't back draws.

The Blackburn game I had no opinions on but generally speaking it's a good idea to avoid backing teams at odds on away from home. So Mr I picks Arsenal, away at 10/11, too, another team that look likely to start slowly, with key players leaving and their replacements yet to gel with the other players.

Had he placed four singles Mr Ingle would have got most of the money back through Middlesbrough's win, as it is he lost the lot. Let this be a lesson to him and to you all. Happy punting.

webTitle: Single sex lessons plan to counter laddish culture

fields.headline: Single sex lessons plan to counter laddish culture
fields.standfirst: Blunkett promises to give teachers ammunition to tackle 'anti-learning' attitude that leaves boys trailing in the wake of girl high flyers
fields.trailText: Single-sex teaching for some subjects will be introduced into mixed state schools if evidence shows it can improve boys' performance, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Single-sex teaching for some subjects will be introduced into mixed state schools if evidence shows it can improve boys' performance, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.

Mr Blunkett blamed the growing academic gender divide on a "laddish anti-learning culture", and said deep-seated cultural issues needed to be confronted.

The education secretary said he would give schools "ammunition" to tackle the poor performance of boys, amid a wave of concern about the gender gap in education, which is set to be heightened by GCSE results this week.

On Thursday girls are expected to extend their already substantial lead at GCSE, a week after results showed them achieving more A grades than boys at A-level for the first time.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, accused Mr Blunkett of interfering in schools with the initiative and "clutching at straws".

Since 1998, local education authorities have been expected to include proposals to improve boys' results in their education development plans. Mr Blunkett now wants to examine their success and intends to enlist the help of Chris Woodhead, the head of Ofsted, the office for standards in education, when he returns from holiday next week.

"It is now time to see how well these are working and I will be speaking to Ofsted about the role it might play in helping gather the evidence, including pilot programmes already running, in respect of single-sex teaching of some subjects in coeducational schools," Mr Blunkett said.

"We will pin down what works well and ensure schools and education authorities have ammunition to turn around boys' academic performance."

A "gender and achievement" website is being launched by the Department for Education and Employment for the start of the new school year, to give advice and enable schools to share best practice. There will be a series of regional conferences on the issue with education experts.

Officials stressed that there was no question of turning schools from coeducational schools into single-sex establishments. Nor are they planning to introduce more pilot schemes. Some educationalists doubt that imposing single-sex teaching can make in itself a significant difference.

The education secretary said it should not be forgotten that boys as well as girls were achieving better results. "However, we face a genuine problem of underachievement among boys, particularly those from working class families.

"This underachievement is linked to a laddish culture which in many areas has grown out of deprivation and a lack of self-confidence and opportunity," Mr Blunkett said.

"The gap that has opened up between the sexes at school is a long-standing and international problem for which there is no quick fix, but I am determined that our boys should not miss out.

"Together, schools, parents and the government need to play their part to instil a cultural commitment to learning among boys. That way we can begin to reverse the gap in achievement between boys and girls that has been such a feature of the last decade."

This is not a new preoccupation for Mr Blunkett. His 1998 guidance was introduced as the then schools minister, Stephen Byers, warned: "We must challenge the laddish anti-learning culture which has developed and we simply can not accept, with a shrug of our shoulders that 'boys will be boys'."

Mr Woodhead's concern pre-dates that. In March 1996 he caused controversy by warning: "The failure of boys, and in particular white working-class boys, is one of the most disturbing problems we face within the whole of the education system."

Since GCSEs were introduced, girls have done better than boys and the gap continues to widen. In 1989 35.8% of girls and 29.8% of boys obtained five or more A-Cs at GCSE; in 1999 53.2% of girls and 42.6% of boys achieved the same results. In English, the divide is even more startling; 61% of girls achieved an A-C last year, compared with 45% of boys.

At degree level, male students narrowly achieve more firsts.

Mr Blunkett said the government was "already having some success in narrowing the gender gap in the early years". Government literacy and numeracy strategies were helping to prevent boys falling behind girls. In key stage 2 tests last year, 11-year-old boys closed the gap by five percentage points to 11% in English, and matched girls in maths.

He claimed other measures addressed the issue, including learning mentors for disaffected pupils, £140m to help excluded pupils, integrated careers advice and youth services, and the development of vocational GCSEs and A-levels.

Mr Blunkett said boys needed "better male role models" inside and outside school.

He pointed to primary and nursery schools, where 83% of teachers are women, although he claimed inquiries from men about postgraduate teaching courses were up 50% since the government announced its £6,000 training bursaries.

Primary school reading lists had been changed to make books more stimulating for boys, professional footballers were being enlisted to help promote after-school study centres, and Harry Enfield's teenage character Kevin was encouraging people to stay in education and training after GCSE as part of the government's "Don't quit now" campaign.

But Ms May dismissed the initiative: "This is yet another example of this government interfering in schools and telling teachers what to do. David Blunkett is clutching at straws."

David Hart, the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said the government lacked a coherent strategy for addressing laddish behaviour which led to poor results.

"Unless we grab the boys early at primary school age and in the first three years of secondary school at the very latest to persuade them that anti-academic attitudes are simply leading them down a potentially disastrous path - and also get the parents on side - I think all this talk about segregating the sexes will have no effect."

webTitle: Scottish heads call for right to have every exam result checked

fields.headline: Scottish heads call for right to have every exam result checked
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The crisis surrounding Scottish examinations deepened yesterday as headteachers called for schools to have the power to check every result amid allegations that some students' exam papers had gone missing.
fields.body:
The crisis surrounding Scottish examinations deepened yesterday as headteachers called for schools to have the power to check every result amid allegations that some students' exam papers had gone missing.

A grim picture of chaos at the Scottish Qualifications Authority was becoming apparent as 3,000 of the students who have been barred from the university clearing process because of erroneous results learned they would have to wait even longer to get their grades.

The authority confirmed yesterday that 2,000 of the 5,000 students known to have inaccurate or incomplete results would have their grades confirmed this morning, but that the remaining students would have to wait longer for their results.

Pressure is growing on the Scottish education minister, Sam Galbraith, to resign. The minister, a close friend of Donald Dewar, is adamant that he will not pay for the outside agency's failings, but he may be unable to ride out the storm.

Much of the crisis stems from what Mr Galbraith and the SQA euphemistically describe as "missing data". But it has emerged that the problems may have been compounded by the SQA's handling of teachers recruited as examination markers.

These markers were not recruited until two months after the normal date, and the amount of teaching experience they were required to have was lowered from three years to two.

It has been alleged that this, and a huge backlog of papers to be marked, led to chaos in the quality control system, with the normal system of checks and balances bypassed or badly compromised.

Donald Matheson, president of the Headteachers' Association of Scotland, said he had grave concerns about the accuracy of some of the marking as anomalous results were double or treble what would normally be expected. "We are calling for schools to be given the right to check papers," he said.

Remarking and checking on a grand scale would add greatly to the cost and political impact of the crisis, but it might be the only way out.

Already the SQA is bracing itself for a large number of appeals against grades, and the Scottish parliament's executive yesterday pledged to make additional resources available to cover the costs.

At one school in Edinburgh, teachers alleged that the higher grade papers of 10 business studies students had been lost by the SQA. Frank Gestenberg, headteacher of George Watson's college, said the alarm was raised after pupils were given fail grades when they and the school expected a pass. "The SQA has now told us the papers have been lost," he said.

However, Bill Morton, interim chief execuitve of the SQA, denied the allegations. "I can say to you categorically that that is not the case. Those papers are within the SQA," he said.

It is certain that SQA officials were aware of the scale of the crisis long before it became public. More than two weeks after the deadline for marking, the SQA was forced to hire a bowling hall and recruit 100 markers in an attempt to tackle its backlog.

Civil servants called in to sort out the quango's problems two weeks ago have confirmed to ministers that the organisation is in chaos. Ministers have known there were problems at the SQA since March, but they are only now learning the extent of the problem.

Although the executive has promised to fund extra university places for every student disadvantaged by the debacle, some students have already contacted lawyers who say they would have strong grounds for suing the SQA for negligence.

fields.headline: The trouble with boys
fields.standfirst:
Getting them to study is no easy matter
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The education secretary signalled his growing concern yesterday at the widening gap between the performance of male and female pupils. He is right to be concerned. Last Thursday, the A-level results showed girls outperforming boys, achieving a higher proportion of A grades for the first time in the 49-year history of the exam.
fields.body:
The education secretary signalled his growing concern yesterday at the widening gap between the performance of male and female pupils. He is right to be concerned. Last Thursday, the A-level results showed girls outperforming boys, achieving a higher proportion of A grades for the first time in the 49-year history of the exam.

This Thursday, the GCSE results are released. The last results showed girls widening the gap in the proportion gaining five good passes (grade C and above) to 10% for the first time - with 53% of girls reaching this benchmark compared with just 43% of boys. But for boys, the government would already have reached its 2002 target of 50% of pupils achieving five good passes. The story for pupils aged 11 is even grimmer, with 61% of girls achieving the expected reading standard, compared with just 46% of boys.

Earlier this summer, the Conservatives called on the government to overhaul GCSE exams, after new figures showed that boys' results were getting worse in more than a fifth of English education authorities. Boys' results deteriorated in 33 areas last year, including even some affluent suburbs. Theresa May, the Tory education spokeswoman, blamed the introduction of course work, which is more suited to girls, with their readiness to work more systematically and conscientiously than boys.

Sensibly, ministers are refusing to take precipitate action. Overall, boys' performance has been improving, but not by nearly as much as that of girls. There is no simple solution to this complex phenomenon. David Blunkett rightly noted yesterday that the problems facing boys were particularly acute, with the disappearance of the old traditional routes into manual and craft employment in the new knowledge-driven global economy. Under-achievement by any group - gender, race or class - must be tackled if equal opportunities are to be promoted.

This is not the first generation of boys to have regarded serious study at school as "uncool". The spotty, bespectacled swot has always been a figure of derision. But earlier generations appear to have been more ready to study surreptitiously. Bob Geldof explained on Desert Island Discs how shocked he had been at school when his mates who claimed not to have been swotting for exams had clearly been secretly revising. The fact that the biggest current gap in performance is between working-class boys and girls makes the problem more acute for a Labour government intent on creating an inclusive society. Laddish culture crosses all class barriers, but appears to be having the worst effects on the most deprived.

It is two years since local education authorities were asked to introduce programmes to tackle boys' under- achievement. They are now being asked to provide an evaluation of their programmes. Not all the news is bleak. The daily literacy and numeracy hours, introduced into primary schools in 1998, appear to be narrowing the gaps in some tests at 11. Pilot programmes involving single-sex classes in some subjects in mixed schools have produced some promising early results, but will need rigorous evaluation. The education secretary is keen to attract more male teachers to provide more role models for pupils. Only 17% of primary teachers are male, but the new £6,000 training bursaries increased inquiries from male postgraduates by 50%. A wider, more relevant curriculum, with vocational courses linked to job opportunities, would help girls as well as boys - and reduce the number of pupils, currently 80,000, who leave at 16 with no qualifications.

webTitle: Troops back on Belfast streets after shootings

fields.headline: Troops back on Belfast streets after shootings
fields.trailText: Troops were ordered back on to the streets of Belfast tonight after two men were   shot dead, the RUC said.
fields.body:
Troops were ordered back on to the streets of Belfast tonight after two men were shot dead, the RUC said.

The two men were killed today as a loyalist paramilitary feud erupted in new bloodshed. One died immediately after a gunman opened fire on the city's Crumlin Road. The second was seriously wounded in the stomach in the same attack and died later in hospital.

Offices used by political representatives of the rival organisations involved were also hit, one sprayed with gunfire and a second set alight.

The two men were gunned down as they sat in a Range Rover outside a bookmaker's shop.

Both had just walked across the road to the vehicle. Police said a lone gunman emerged from an alleyway and fired at them, then ran back down the alley.

One of the murdered men had links with the Ulster Defence Association (UDA), which immediately blamed the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) for the shootings which signalled a dramatic escalation in the feud which has been simmering for several months. Both sides had earlier warned that people would be killed unless the fighting stopped.

A taxi depot, at least one house and a car were also set ablaze, all in the Shankill area.

Amid reports of armed UDA men roaming the area, two men were arrested and a number of weapons recovered.

Within an hour the offices of the Ulster Democratic Party, the political wing of the UDA, were sprayed by a gunman who opened up from a passing car. ne man was slightly injured.

Retaliation was swift. The offices of the Progressive Unionist Party, the UVF's political wing, a few hundred yards further along the Shankill Road were attacked by an angry mob and set on fire.

RUC officers and gunmen later exchanged shots in the Malvern Street area.

Violence erupted between the two sides in the neighbouring Shankill Road area on Saturday when seven men were injured after UDA gunmen twice sprayed a bar during and after a big loyalist paramilitary rally which they claimed was attacked by the UVF. Homes belonging to members and supporters of the Progressive Party were later attacked.

Earlier today John White of the Ulster Democratic Party called for the appointment of a go-between to try to negotiate an end to the feud, but today's shooting is likely to quash hopes of an immediate truce.

fields.headline: Shayler charged and released
fields.trailText: Former M15 agent David Shayler was tonight released on police bail after being charged with two offences relating to disclosure in contravention of the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
Former M15 agent David Shayler was tonight released on police bail after being charged with two offences relating to disclosure in contravention of the Official Secrets Act.

Mr Shayler, 34, who was arrested at Dover port immediately on arrival in Britain this morning, was taken to Charing Cross police station for questioning following three years of "political exile" in France.

Appearing after his release with his lawyer John Wadham, Mr Shayler said: "I decided to return to Britain to face charges under the Official Secrets Act.

"I have done this to clear my name and to allow a jury of 12 of my fellow citizens to judge me. I have also returned to challenge the cover-up and complacency that has followed my disclosures."

Mr Shayler said he is not being prosecuted for any allegations made after August 24 1997, which include his claims that MI6 were behind a bungled plot to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gaddafi, and that the security services failed to act on a warning about the Bishopsgate bomb.

He added that police had not questioned him on his allegations of the Gaddafi plot. He faces prosecution only over claims of incompetence by his former employers, MI5.

"The government is backing off. It doesn't want to fight. It is restricting its charges to what was in the public domain," Mr Wadham said.

Mr Shayler said: "The authorities want to restrict the charges to what was revealed in the Mail on Sunday in August 1997, but I wonder whether this is an attempt to prevent the jury from hearing the whole story."

European human rights legislation, to be introduced in Britain this autumn, may provide a defence to "whistle-blowers" prosecuted under the Official Secrets Act.

Mr Wadham said: "The Official Secrets Act will have to read in a way that gives more respect to freedom of expression and the public interest in disclosure.

"David Shayler's case will test the extent to which this theory works in practice."

Mr Shayler fled to France in 1997 after claiming in the Mail on Sunday that two MI6 officers were behind a failed attempt to assassinate the Libyan leader.

fields.headline: Russian sub: First body found
fields.trailText: Divers have discovered the first body inside the sunken Russian  submarine Kursk after the chief of staff of Russia's Northern Fleet,  Mikhail Motsak, confirmed that all 118 submariners stranded on  the sunken vessel had died.
fields.body:
Divers have discovered the first body inside the sunken Russian submarine Kursk after the chief of staff of Russia's Northern Fleet, Mikhail Motsak, confirmed that all 118 submariners stranded on the sunken vessel had died.

"A body was found in the ninth section near the escape hatch," Russian state television said in a live report from a ship at the rescue site in the Barents sea. "The body will be transported [to the surface]. They will try to retrieve it with a robot arm."

Earlier, Norwegian divers who entered the crippled submarine this morning said they were certain that the entire submarine was flooded and all those on board were dead. "The inner section is full of water. The commander of the operation believes there is no one alive aboard," a spokesman for the Norwegian armed forces said after divers inspected the sunken Kursk.

A fragment of a foreign submarine, probably British, has been found near the. But an unidentified military source, cited by Interfax, has cautioned that it is too early to make any conclusions because the submarine fragment could have been lying there for years.

fields.headline: Market leaders
fields.standfirst: Shopping, telly and driving are the big sellers so far this year.  John Dugdale  dissects the latest magazine circulation figures and finds the glossies in decline, while Asda, Sky TV and the AA are shifting more copies than ever
fields.trailText: Shopping, telly and driving are the big sellers so far this year. John Dugdale dissects the latest magazine circulation figures and finds the glossies in decline, while Asda, Sky TV and the AA are shifting more copies than ever
fields.body:
If you were starting a magazine company intent on gargantuan sales then, judging by the latest batch of half-yearly ABC figures, you wouldn't go for the glamorous part of the sector - the monthly women's and men's glossies. Both are now "mature" markets, like old-style women's weeklies. Which means that, with the odd exception (usually due to relaunches, free cover-mount giveaways, intensive promotion, rising editors replacing duff ones, etc), they face remorseless, drip-drip sales erosion. Each February and August brings bad news.

Nor would you go for computer mags, despite the evidence of the average newsstand: titles tend to be linked to particular games-makers or PC companies, fragmenting the market. Portfolios of PC and internet titles have helped to boost newer publishers such as Future and Dennis, but their individual circulations are usually low.

No, you'd choose unisex sectors - where circulations are not halved by the glossies' gender split - which involve the nation's favourite waking-hours activities: shopping, telly and driving.

The top five supermarket mags have a combined circulation of 3,832,990 (even though Tesco, the biggest chain, doesn't bother publishing one); chuck in the Boots and Superdrug titles, and you add another 2,976,917. The top 10 TV titles rack up 11,336,061 copies between them. AA Magazine alone goes to 4,374,601 motorists. Bear in mind that, in these sectors, many of these magazines are not what ABC calls "actively purchased" (Sky Customer Magazine, for instance, goes to all subscribers). But the figures are still spectacular.

Of these sectors, the TV listings market - volatile, and pitching traditional publishers against contract companies, long-established paid-for mags against free titles - is easily the most fascinating. The Jan-June 2000 figures show sales of the old stalwarts, Radio Times (1,250,134, down 10% year on year) and TV Times (705,347, down 14.6%), continuing to droop among the paid-for group, while IPC's What's On TV (1,707,815) was down 5.8% year on year but still way ahead of the Bauer challengers, TV Quick (578,796) and TV Choice (784,904) - the latter an autumn 1999 launch posting its first ABC. The sector's really big hitters, though, are the free titles for pay-TV viewers, Cable Guide (1,820,092) and the two Sky mags. Here the big change is a massive migration from analogue Skyview (1,427,789) to digital Sky Customer (ex-Skyview Digital; 2,644,874), giving the latter an astronomical but deceptive year on year rise of 479.1%.

Each six-monthly set of results also provides an opportunity to see how starkly specific commercial reality matches up to the buoyant mission statements made by high-profile, usually first-time editors in the easygoing interviews that accompanied their arrival. Tory candidate and Have I Got News For You buffoon Boris Johnson, for example, replaced Frank Johnson in the editor's seat at the Spectator almost exactly a year ago - so this is the first full sales period for the weekly since he put his stamp on it. Its performance is strong but not dazzling, with sales of 59,747 continuing an upward movement (up 3.8% year on year, 2.2% period on period) which nevertheless appears to be slowing. With a new editor expected to be installed shortly, the Spec is a long way ahead of the New Statesman (21,876) and Prospect (16,761), but still under half the circulation of the Economist's UK edition (127,887).

Geordie Greig, hired with much fanfare last year to replace Jane Procter at Tatler, has created a buzz about the title - Jerry Hall and Nicola Formby were made contributing editors, several interviews have been followed up by the national press, and (as with Alexandra Shulman at Vogue) links have been forged with the Telegraph titles.

So far, however, the bottom-line result is stasis: in August 1999, Procter's last full ABC was 85,873; a year later, Greig's first full ABC is 85,428 (up 0.29% period on period). But Condé Nast is bullish about the 11.49% jump in newsstand sales - almost certainly the result of the sharper news sense that the ex-Sunday Times books editor has sought to achieve.

At Marie Claire, Liz Jones - high-profile thanks to her remarkably candid, currently mistitled Single File confessional column in the Sunday Times's Style section - produced her first issue last July, so this is her second ABC judgment day. With a latest figure of 420,146 (down 4% year on year, 6.7% period on period), she has still to halt the fall in the monthly's sales since the days of founding editor Glenda Bailey. Marie Claire's results are roughly in line with the general trend in a sector where other former star performers such as Bella, Company, Prima and Red are also losing readers; Elle (219,377) and Woman's Journal (124,163, up 20.3% year on year, though down on the previous period) were among the few to post gains.

Looking at magland's long-running head-to-heads, the biggest news is that Hello! (458,663) has just managed to snatch back the lead in the weekly celebrity title market from OK! (455,162), after being humiliatingly overhauled in the second half of last year by a challenger making huge percentage gains every six months. Hello!'s own sales have actually declined, but its rival's figure of 551,901 in July-Dec 1999 was inflated by demand for issues covering the wedding of Posh and Becks and proved unsustainable.

As for the battle between GQ's Dylan Jones - by now notorious for removing bits of young women's clothing without their consent (digitally, on his covers, as with the men's mag's classy "Kylie's bum" front) - and Esquire's Peter Howarth, who has made much of taking a stance against laddism by cutting back on bared babes, victory has gone to the former: Condé Nast's GQ (138,177) shed sales but nevertheless lengthened its lead because the NatMags title (70,435) suffered a horrendous 30% slump, both year on year and period on period.

Group publisher Lizzie Kershaw's defence, nostalgically familiar to aficionados of BBC spin on tumbling audience figures in the John Birt years (as in the "sliding down the Bannister" era at Radio 1) was that "we knew when we refocused Esquire that an initial fall in circulation was likely but now we have a fantastic product and are building a loyal set of intelligent, sharper readers".

In the bitter feud between the posh monthlies, Tatler - already ahead in UK newsstand sales, Condé Nast contends - looks poised to overtake its NatMags counterpart Harpers & Queen in the next period. Although Tatler remained virtually static with Greig at the helm, the 5.3% year-on-year drop at Fiona Mcpherson's Harpers & Queen (87,123) narrowed the latter's lead to under 2,000 copies.

In the declining women's monthly market, the rivalry between NatMags' Cosmo, the long standing market leader, and IPC's Marie Claire was sharpened when the June-Dec 1999 figures came out in February by the latter's claim that it was now on top ("ridiculous" said NatMags supremo Terry Mansfield). The relative newcomer was 14,841 ahead in news-stand sales, although subscriptions allowed Cosmo to stay on top.

Supremacy in Jan-June 2000 was always going to be decided by which title lost fewer readers. Cosmo, in the last full period of Mandi Norwood's editorship - Lorraine Butler is already installed, but the first issue commissioned by her is due in October - held on comfortably with 450,057 (down 4.3% year on year), nearly 30,000 ahead of Marie Claire. Duncan Edwards, NatMags' deputy MD and Mansfield's heir apparent, was even able to crow that it had "overtaken Marie Claire on the newsstand".

There's a twist in the tail, however. Candis, an upstart, Cheshire-based subscription title no bigger than the average paperback novel, posted only a modest 1.4% year-on-year hike and not a single copy was "actively purchased" at a newsstand. But, combined with Cosmo's slide, its rise to 456,169 took it to the top of the monthly sector. Cosmo is no longer No 1. Or only No 1 with an annoying little proviso.

Additional research by Jemima Sissons

fields.headline: Life's a pitch
fields.standfirst: Life in the PR business isn't all fast living and big bucks.  Julian Henry  on the ingratitude and soul-destroying graft behind the corporate presentation
fields.trailText: Life in the PR business isn't all fast living and big bucks. Julian Henry on the ingratitude and soul-destroying graft behind the corporate presentation
fields.body:
Two months ago we were approached out of the blue by a major food corporation with an invitation to pitch for the publicity contract to launch a new type of frozen food.

They said that they liked the PR work that we had done for Tango, and asked if we could bring some of that creative thinking to their product. Our first response was, predictably, to get very excited. If they were serious, it would mean a multi-million-pound advertising spend. The company in question is a household name and we would be working with real professionals.

They refused to tell us any more about the project until we had signed a confidentiality contract. This meant we would be forbidden to talk about the product and their plans without their permission for all eternity. If we broke this agreement, we would have their lawyers to deal with. So we signed. If this was supposed to give us the impression that they were serious heavyweights, well, they succeeded. One of our team was dispatched to take the brief, face to face, along with three other wannabe PR agency hopefuls.

When the details of the project arrived back at our office it was something of an anti-climax. The product was a peculiar variation on packaged food for busy people. It was frozen, but it was also fresh. And it was packaged in groovy silver foil to attract gullible 18-34-year-olds.

We held a meeting and mulled it over. Someone suggested that we drop it and not bother getting involved. Our team of 14 consultants was busy enough on PR campaigns for Absolut Vodka, The Big Breakfast, Top of the Pops Magazine, American Airlines and S Club 7, without having to go chasing after new business.

But I held firm. I was thinking greedily about how the brand name would look on our client list. I told the team that this pitch would challenge us, and that if nothing else, we would certainly learn from it.

And so we had 10 days to prepare. Our first move was to pull in a freelance PR director - she cost £500 a day - and negotiate a chunk of her time to help come up with a strategy to win the business.

Next we conducted an audit, talking to groups of consumers to put a sense of perspective around the product. Would people actually buy the stuff? How challenging was it? Where in the supermarket would it be sold?

Another job was to create "mood boards". This entailed going through piles of magazines and newspapers to compile a picture of the target consumers' habits, how they shopped for food and how generally they lived their lives. By this stage we had analysed the brief to the point of knowing it off by heart. We had started to get an understanding of what might be needed to generate front-page news for the product.

But still we needed more information. The brief was vague on some points and even contradicted itself. So we asked if we could talk to the advertising agency. They had been busy at work on the project for over six months. Unfortunately we were told, "No."

This was strange. Quite often, the advertising is more interesting and newsworthy than the product itself. Without the benefit of knowing what the advertising would be, we felt like we were shooting in the dark.

Still, we ploughed on, and with four days to go we held another meeting to review our work. We decided to go for broke with an idea that had the potential to put the brand into every tabloid newspaper in the country.

By the day of the pitch, our document was 52 pages long. We had created a series of elaborate tables and presentation boards. In a little under two weeks, we had completed a crash course in frozen-food marketing and PR.

My wife had even started to contribute, waking me up in the middle of the night to tell me that she'd had an idea. The four of us loaded up the car and drove off down the motorway to the corporate HQ where the meeting was due to take place.

Unfortunately the pitch did not live up to our expectations. It was a miserable affair. The product manager - a serious-looking woman in her late 20s - sat next to two corporate PR executives. Both of them were distracted because of a crisis elsewhere in the office. Apparently cod had just become an endangered species. Next to them was a smiling man from the advertising agency who was doodling on his pad.

Our presentation took an hour and a half. We sold our ideas as if our lives depended upon it. No questions were asked. Our attempts at witty remarks were greeted by vacant expressions.

At one point, desperate for some form of feedback, we asked them a question. It became apparent from the reply that they had not understood a word we had been saying. We were too embarrassed to make anything of it.

As we crawled through the last set of ideas it suddenly occurred to me that we should stop the presentation, down tools, and walk out there and then. This sort of confrontation in a pitch scenario is always the kiss of death because most people - especially uncertain clients - hate being put on the spot. It means that they might have to think spontaneously and without being able to spend a month analysing all the issues. But I decided against it. We continued meekly laying our work out on the table in the hope of getting some sort of response. As we stood up to leave the product manager said to me, "Thank you, John." She'd even forgotten my name. I asked them for business cards. They had none.

We drove back to London with heavy hearts. It was obvious that the pitch had not gone well. The clients had had nothing to say about our ideas. But what started to rile me was their total lack of interest in what we, as outsiders, might think of their project. All we had faced was a wall of corporate stodge. They had been in an advanced state of analysis paralysis throughout the meeting.

I began to feel angry. The rest of the team said that I was being unreasonable, that we had just taken the wrong tack, and anyway we might still be in with a chance. I said grumpily that I didn't want to work for them, even if we did win it.

It came as no surprise when, two days later, we were telephoned and told that we had lost the pitch. No explanation was given. No thank-yous were offered for the time and effort that we had dedicated to the project.

We held a debrief meeting and I asked everyone what they had taken out of the project. We all agreed it had been fun working as a team on something unusual like a new type of food. Someone said they were surprised at how boring the people looked at corporate HQ.

In financial terms, it cost us £2,000 in materials. We would also have charged around £10,000 for the time that we put into the ideas and strategy. We have no protection against these ideas being used once we have presented them, though in this case it would seem unlikely.

PR agencies and advertising agencies go through this process every day of the week as they punt for new business. To me this has started to seem like an outdated concept. Our world is about working with companies for mutual advantage, in exchanges of ideas and in cooperating to build networks that might bring shared benefits.

Our clients understand this and our working relationship is built on trust and respect for each other, both as companies and as individuals. Though PR is an industry that is littered with intangibles, it is a place where great creative ideas can make a million pounds' worth of difference.

I look at the experience of pitching to a corporation in this way and try to think what good it has done us. Very little, it seems. At the very least I would have hope that we could learn from the experience.

In the event, all that I can say that we have taken from this process is the knowledge that it is sometimes better to lose than it is to win.

Julian Henry is a director of Henry's House PR agency.

We decided to go for broke with an idea that had the potential to put the brand into every tabloid newspaper in the country. By the day of the pitch, our document was 52 pages long. We had created a series of elaborate tables and presentation boards. In a little under two weeks, we had completed a crash course in frozen-food marketing and PR. My wife had even started to contribute, waking me up in the middle of the night to tell me that she'd had an idea. The four of us loaded up the car and drove off down the motorway to the corporate HQ where the meeting was due to take place. Unfortunately the pitch did not live up to our expectations. It was a miserable affair. The product manager - a serious-looking woman in her late 20s - sat next to two corporate PR executives. Both of them were distracted because of a crisis elsewhere in the office. Apparently cod had just become an endangered species. Next to them was a smiling man from the advertising agency who was doodling on his pad. Our presentation took an hour and a half. We sold our ideas as if our lives depended upon it. No questions were asked. Our attempts at witty remarks were greeted by vacant expressions. At one point, desperate for some form of feedback, we asked them a question. It became apparent from the reply that they had not understood a word we had been saying. We were too embarrassed to make anything of it. As we crawled through the last set of ideas it suddenly occurred to me that we should stop the presentation, down tools, and walk out there and then. This sort of confrontation in a pitch scenario is always the kiss of death because most people - especially uncertain clients - hate being put on the spot. It means that they might have to think spontaneously and without being able to spend a month analysing all the issues. But I decided against it. We continued meekly laying our work out on the table in the hope of getting some sort of response. As we stood up to leave the product manager said to me, "Thank you, John." She'd even forgotten my name. I asked them for business cards. They had none. We drove back to London with heavy hearts. It was obvious that the pitch had not gone well. The clients had had nothing to say about our ideas. But what started to rile me was their total lack of interest in what we, as outsiders, might think of their project. All we had faced was a wall of corporate stodge. They had been in an advanced state of analysis paralysis throughout the meeting. I began to feel angry. The rest of the team said that I was being unreasonable, that we had just taken the wrong tack, and anyway we might still be in with a chance. I said grumpily that I didn't want to work for them, even if we did win it. It came as no surprise when, two days later, we were telephoned and told that we had lost the pitch. No explanation was given. No thank-yous were offered for the time and effort that we had dedicated to the project. We held a debrief meeting and I asked everyone what they had taken out of the project. We all agreed it had been fun working as a team on something unusual like a new type of food. Someone said they were surprised at how boring the people looked at corporate HQ. In financial terms, it cost us £2,000 in materials. We would also have charged around £10,000 for the time that we put into the ideas and strategy. We have no protection against these ideas being used once we have presented them, though in this case it would seem unlikely. PR agencies and advertising agencies go through this process every day of the week as they punt for new business. To me this has started to seem like an outdated concept. Our world is about working with companies for mutual advantage, in exchanges of ideas and in cooperating to build networks that might bring shared benefits. Our clients understand this and our working relationship is built on trust and respect for each other, both as companies and as individuals. Though PR is an industry that is littered with intangibles, it is a place where great creative ideas can make a million pounds' worth of difference. I look at the experience of pitching to a corporation in this way and try to think what good it has done us. Very little, it seems. At the very least I would have hope that we could learn from the experience. In the event, all that I can say that we have taken from this process is the knowledge that it is sometimes better to lose than it is to win. Julian Henry is a director of Henry's House PR agency.

fields.headline: Commercial travellers
fields.standfirst: US drivers are cashing in by turning their cars into mobile billboards.  Gillian Drummond  on a trend that could hit the British highway soon
fields.trailText: US drivers are cashing in by turning their cars into mobile billboards. Gillian Drummond on a trend that could hit the British highway soon
fields.body:
London taxis have been doing it for years, buses for even longer, and retailers do it with every delivery truck they send out on the road. Plastering advertisements on vehicles is nothing new. But the latest trend in the US goes one step further.

Two new companies in California are paying the public to have their cars wrapped in advertisements and brand logos, and drivers are signing up in their thousands. The cars are fully covered in a high-quality vinyl adhesive, guaranteed not to damage paintwork when it is removed. The ad can be for anything from Head & Shoulders to Andersen Consulting, and the gaudier and more traffic-stopping the better. And in return for becoming mobile billboards, drivers are paid up to $400 a month for as long as a campaign runs. One of these companies, FreeCar Media, is even giving people brand-new cars to drive around for two years. All the driver pays for is petrol and insurance.

The firms act as middlemen, matching drivers with suitable brands. Young executives, for example, may be good for promoting an investment firm. Fitness enthusiasts who frequent gyms and the outdoors could help sell bottled water. Families could promote a new theme park. It's not only novel, they say, it's high exposure; the average American spends two hours a day in his car and drives over 40 miles. And for the drivers, it's payback time - an opportunity to make money out of the very companies that have bled consumers for years.

"The US advertising industry is worth $215bn and we're putting a portion of that back into consumers' pockets," says Daniel Shifrin, president and founder of Autowraps.com which, since its January launch, has signed up 50,000 drivers in 15 states, and 40 advertisers. These include Procter & Gamble, Kraft Foods, Coca-Cola and several dot.com start-ups. Shifrin, whose idea came to him in a traffic jam, has wrapped around 350 cars so far, and says his San Francisco company is growing "like a virus".

Lawrence Butler, chairman and co-founder of rival firm FreeCar Media in Los Angeles, says he was inspired by the wrapped buses he saw in LA and New York. "I thought, why not on private vehicles? If you're on the freeway or the car's parked across the street, you can't just ignore it." And he claims clients get not just mobile ads, but mobile salespeople. "People are so inquisitive about the cars they're rolling their windows down and asking drivers to talk about it, so the driver becomes an ambassador for the product."

There's no chance of drivers pocketing the cash and hiding the car in their garage. Vehicles are inspected monthly for mileage and condition (Autowraps.com insists they're washed at least once a month) and FreeCar Media installs electronic mapping devices that allow advertisers to keep track of where their drivers are going.

Both firms plan to expand internationally; FreeCar Media, with 100,000 drivers and four advertisers, already has drivers signed up in London. And both want to use their cars for non-profit causes. Butler and his team paid for cars to be driven around during last week's Democratic national convention in LA urging people to vote (although they were wrapped, in rather partisan style, in large photos of Al Gore). Shifrin is talking to anti-drink-driving groups and says he wants to persuade anti-smoking organisations to pay teenagers to drive cars emblazoned with logos such as "Smoking sucks".

Dominique Hanssens, Bud Knapp Professor of Marketing at UCLA, sees car wrapping taking off: "There's a good deal of burnout and saturation with traditional media. Most people simply zap through commercials on TV, so traditional advertising is not getting the reach advertisers pay for." The problem, says Hanssens, is overkill. "If it becomes every third or fourth car that's wrapped, people will zap through that mentally too. But it's unusual, and I'm not surprised it originated here. It sounds crazy enough."

The folks at American Esquire magazine thought the same thing when they were looking for an April Fool's article for their spring issue. Unaware of the existence of the two firms, contributing editor Ted Fishman dreamed up a bogus internet start-up called FreeWheelz that gave away free cars and financed them by wrapping the vehicles in ads. He even went so far as to set up a fictitious company website to back up his article.

But no one got the joke, and soon Esquire was fielding calls and emails from willing drivers and intrigued reporters alike. "Ted thought, what's the most absurd business plan I can think of? But it just wasn't over-the-top enough," concedes Peter Griffin, Esquire's deputy editor.

"It's a reflection on our society that by the time he came up with the idea, pitched it to his editors, and had the thing printed, there were companies already doing it," says Butler, who admits to a feeling of panic when he first saw the article. FreeCar Media was just about to launch, and when Butler got in touch, the lads at Esquire saw a business opportunity. "They said, if that many people are signing up there's something in it," says Butler. So they sold him the names they had gathered, plus rights to the FreeWheelz website. Butler learned that there may be such a thing as a free car, but not a free car website. The cost to him? A cool $25,000.

fields.headline: Uneasy partners
fields.standfirst: Channel 4's TV and web documentary of marriage breakdown is a flawed experiment.  Fiona Morrow  asks if the two media can ever be truly compatible
fields.trailText: Channel 4's TV and web documentary of marriage breakdown is a flawed experiment. Fiona Morrow asks if the two media can ever be truly compatible.
fields.body:
When the pilot of Channel 4's experimental TV/web convergence series aired late last year, it was greeted with something like horror from the press. Some found it too voyeuristic or exploitative, most just hated the people in it; why, they asked, should we be subjected to these loathsome, middle-class narcissists, who know too much about the power of television to ever truly kneel down before it?

Yet to begin with, Smart Hearts had sounded exciting: the subjects of an initial documentary - a couple whose marriage has broken down, and the husband's new partner - would subsequently be webcast for six months, the results of and response to which would form the basis of a series. An experiment in the possibilities of convergence, it was commissioned by C4; it was at the right place, at the right time. Or so it seemed.

With the spectacle of the various weird wannabes currently taking up space on our schedules and terminals from the Big Brother house, much of the speculation about Smart Hearts already seems oddly anachronistic; as the country becomes embroiled in the gameshow's bitching premise, the round-the-clock eavesdropping extravaganza doesn't seem that off the wall.

On paper even the subjects of Smart Hearts don't sound too different from those of much of C4's increasingly homogenous output - obnoxious, vain, frequently drunk and verbally aggressive. However, unlike the away-from-it-all population of the various Uncovered series they are engaged enough to challenge both our perceptions and their involvement. And if that involvement at times takes solipsism to breathtaking heights, at least they aren't in it for a cash pay-out or a career in the media.

But while the experiences of Brendan, his soon-to-be ex-wife Claire and new girlfriend Lisa's excruciatingly self-conscious parody of their lives are rather enjoyable and their mordantly thorough introspection is grotesquely compelling, it soon becomes apparent that the basic premise of the series - the experiment in convergence - hadn't come off.

Very little of Smart Hearts on television is informed by the web side of the project, leaving us with what is basically another narrative docu-soap, crudely glueing together the sensational moments from a lengthy filming period. And, it must be said, a lingering impression that all we have learned about this unholy trinity is not necessarily what it appears. "Everyone was hamming it up. Most definitely," says Lisa. "I've come to realise there is no such thing as documentary - I'm acting, so whatever you're getting, it isn't real life. And if that's Brendan, I'm not living with him." The gap between the depiction and the reality she found hilarious: "I was very taken aback by the press response to the pilot - that nobody thought it was funny. They should have been scratching their heads and asking if they had been hoodwinked."

When I ask the director of Smart Hearts, Victoria Mapplebeck, if the joke is really on us, she looks concerned: "I get worried when you use terms like set-up," she admits. "That issue - when does the real stop and the artificial begin? - is at the very heart of documentary. Is documentary ever real?"

She winces when I suggest that the attempt at convergence failed. "I can't say failed, but its strengths are in the relationship stuff that would have happened anyway."

It's worth pointing out, as it isn't explained in the series, that Mapplebeck and her artist subjects are friends, and the piece is to form the backbone of a PhD the director is working on. Inevitably, both of these facts bring an element of compromise to a documentary project, and Mapplebeck's position is infuriatingly woolly: "It's creative documentary, it's reality TV, and that's what we're working with," she proffers ambiguously.

The more she is pushed on what she tried to do, the more confusing is her response: "I wanted an intimacy and an intensity," she explains. "I wanted to make an antidote to the docu-soap and return to documentary portraiture of old - cinéma vérité, and the way that manifested with Paul Watson's The Family." But then she says: "The starting point was the whole artifice of what documentary culture is, and the concept that there can ever be an objective truth which is mediated."

Question whether the two ideas are compatible, and she shrugs: "As long as you're getting to something interesting."

As far as Mapplebeck is concerned, whatever we might consider Smart Hearts to be, the one thing she is adamant about is that it is an authored work - in fashionable television vernacular, what is known as a signature documentary. Yet if we are to salvage anything stimulating and provocative from this unfulfilled experiment, then it is not Mapplebeck's largely ineffective and often apparently spurious self-reflexive directorial interjections, but the unrestrained venom of Brendan's diaries and Claire's bizarrely mannered on-screen image; it is perhaps not so much that these subjects are too smart for their own programme, rather that they are too smart for this director.

"There must be over 300 hours of footage," Brendan suggests. "You just get bored and start rehearsing things over in your mind before you turn on the camera." He's disappointed that the programmes have taken a traditional narrative approach: "They're so short you only get the dramatic moments. I don't think it's fair and I'm certainly not happy with it. It's like looking in the mirror another way; the media are the Antichrist." He's laughing, but both he and Lisa were upset by the level of personal criticism they suffered following the pilot: "Television is judged by different criteria from other media," says Lisa. "In art we are accustomed to a much higher level of acceptance, and it was shocking to be pummelled."

The web side of the project was more interesting to all three: "I could move those cameras wherever I wanted," says Claire. "The website was my gallery space." She, like the others, brushes off any suggestion that they may have been exploited: "I only expose myself if I'm asked what I consider to be a decent question, otherwise I keep quiet. It took a long time for Victoria to get into my head."

If Smart Hearts, and the 24-hour webcasts which proliferate on the net prove anything, it is that greater access doesn't equal more insight; it is merely the illusion of disclosure. Mapplebeck bristles: "You can do a portrait of someone which can be a portrait of a performance - I'm going 3D, but I'm not saying that means I'm going inside, that I'm getting the absolute essence of a person. Documentary is a relationship about who's seducing who, and to me, when that's an open text, that's good television."

webTitle: Watercolours, Fire squads and Down to earth

fields.headline: Watercolours, Fire squads and Down to earth
fields.trailText: DON'T BE SO RUUD
fields.body:
DON'T BE SO RUUD

It sounded like such a good idea. The Imperial Lord Ferg would invite knackered Dutchman Ruud van Nistelrooy over to Manchester this autumn to help in his rehabilitation. He would take part in training with the United squad, look at some of Jaap Stam's stirring watercolours, and be given a personal tour around David Beckham's collection of spangly belts. It would have been a rare treat for the Lowlander as far as the Imperial Lord was concerned. But were PSV Eindhoven having any of it? Were they edam.

You see, PSV have this idea in their heads that, because van Nistelrooy is their player, it isn't up to United to decide who he trains with. Silly idea we know, but it hasn't stopped them getting hot under the collar about it. Just look at PSV chairman Harry van Raay fly off the handle. "I think Ferguson should be ashamed of himself. This is very rude of Manchester United. It's unbelievable. I can hardly imagine that someone can call himself Sir and yet say these crazy words. It's a mad idea. I'm asking myself, how does Ferguson think?"

By exchanging chemical signals across different parts of his brain, we assume. But biology, and excitable chairmen aside, PSV do have a point. The Dutch champions are paying van Nistelrooy's wages, and stumping up for his medical treatment, so they don't want to risk their striker having a setback. As PSV's spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt put it: "What happens if he goes to Manchester and gets injured or his rehabilitation slows down? Are United then going to say they don't want him?" Somebody call Yuri Geller - this bloke's psychic!

RED OR DEAD (BORING)

Patrick Vieira will play for Arsenal tonight against Liverpool. This is the astonishing decision that has rocked the world of football to it foundations. In fact, the foundations are so rocked that cracks have started to appear and footballing builders have had to be called in to apply a new layer of soccer concrete. That's how bad it is.

Vieira, of course, was sent off at the Stadium of Light on Saturday for applying his elbow to Darren Williams' cheekbone (he was attempting to buff up his rouge, apparently). Arsene Wenger then supported his player, as managers (except ones with the initials JG) tend to do. He also implied that Williams had overdone the face-clutching that followed the tackle. Williams then insisted he was as honest as the day was long, and wobbly football pundits started talking about the red mist descending at Highbury for the zillionth time.

Vieira meanwhile has apologised to his teammates on behalf of his elbow, and will serve a three-match ban in September. "Patrick was a bit down at training but he will be okay," Wenger said today. "He is a very strong character. He will play against Liverpool." So let that be an end to it. Until the next time a prominent footballer gets a red card, when the Fiver will personally be forming a vigilante squad to burn them out of town.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"[Big Cup] is run by the game, on behalf of the game for the benefit of the family of football" - You don't say. Premier League spokesman Philip French on why Big Cup is so much better than any horrible Super League spin-off.

HOW TO MAKE WAVES AND IRRITATE PEOPLE

If you had just joined a major Premiership team for £3m, the first thing on your mind would be to win the fans over. And if, for example, your first match didn't go that well - you could have walked about aimlessly for example, before getting booked for falling over - the last thing you would want to do was give the impression you'd rather be somewhere else. Wouldn't you?

"I never wanted to leave Tottenham," whined Aston Villa's David Ginola this morning in the caring sharing Daily Mail. "I was pushed out. Tottenham Hotspur Football Club was my entire life. I had given so much to the club for three years and I was looking forward to playing for another two years. Then all of a sudden this manager takes it all away from me."

Holte End regulars may be forgiven for raising a plucked eyebrow at all this. But maybe they shouldn't take it as too big a slight on their club - because we reckon Gin has another agenda, like sticking it up the Tottenham manager, Arsenal's George Graham. "George Graham is living on the edge," the French winger said, sharpening (then shampooing) a knife. "He has to provide something big this year - otherwise he is finished." Unlike Ginola, of course, who is under no pressure to perform and has it all to look forward to.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Aston Villa want to sign Real Madrid's Savio, according to reports. The Brazilian left-winger has, like Steve McManaman, been told his opportunities are limited at the Bernabeu and is available for £7.5m. Villa will, however, face strong competition from Brazilian side Corinthians.

Newcastle and Coventry are in competition over Wimbledon's Jason Euell.

Celta Vigo are interested in Newcastle's misfit defender Marcelino.

Norwich are interested in Colchester's Lomana Tresor Lua Lua as a replacement for £6m Craig Bellamy.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Peter Taylor has reassured Steve Guppy of his future at Leicester after the winger spoke of his displeasure at being left out of the squad against Aston Villa on Saturday. fields.bodyText: DON'T BE SO RUUD It sounded like such a good idea. The Imperial Lord Ferg would invite knackered Dutchman Ruud van Nistelrooy over to Manchester this autumn to help in his rehabilitation. He would take part in training with the United squad, look at some of Jaap Stam's stirring watercolours, and be given a personal tour around David Beckham's collection of spangly belts. It would have been a rare treat for the Lowlander as far as the Imperial Lord was concerned. But were PSV Eindhoven having any of it? Were they edam. You see, PSV have this idea in their heads that, because van Nistelrooy is their player, it isn't up to United to decide who he trains with. Silly idea we know, but it hasn't stopped them getting hot under the collar about it. Just look at PSV chairman Harry van Raay fly off the handle. "I think Ferguson should be ashamed of himself. This is very rude of Manchester United. It's unbelievable. I can hardly imagine that someone can call himself Sir and yet say these crazy words. It's a mad idea. I'm asking myself, how does Ferguson think?" By exchanging chemical signals across different parts of his brain, we assume. But biology, and excitable chairmen aside, PSV do have a point. The Dutch champions are paying van Nistelrooy's wages, and stumping up for his medical treatment, so they don't want to risk their striker having a setback. As PSV's spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt put it: "What happens if he goes to Manchester and gets injured or his rehabilitation slows down? Are United then going to say they don't want him?" Somebody call Yuri Geller - this bloke's psychic! RED OR DEAD (BORING) Patrick Vieira will play for Arsenal tonight against Liverpool. This is the astonishing decision that has rocked the world of football to it foundations. In fact, the foundations are so rocked that cracks have started to appear and footballing builders have had to be called in to apply a new layer of soccer concrete. That's how bad it is. Vieira, of course, was sent off at the Stadium of Light on Saturday for applying his elbow to Darren Williams' cheekbone (he was attempting to buff up his rouge, apparently). Arsene Wenger then supported his player, as managers (except ones with the initials JG) tend to do. He also implied that Williams had overdone the face-clutching that followed the tackle. Williams then insisted he was as honest as the day was long, and wobbly football pundits started talking about the red mist descending at Highbury for the zillionth time. Vieira meanwhile has apologised to his teammates on behalf of his elbow, and will serve a three-match ban in September. "Patrick was a bit down at training but he will be okay," Wenger said today. "He is a very strong character. He will play against Liverpool." So let that be an end to it. Until the next time a prominent footballer gets a red card, when the Fiver will personally be forming a vigilante squad to burn them out of town. QUOTE OF THE DAY "[Big Cup] is run by the game, on behalf of the game for the benefit of the family of football" - You don't say. Premier League spokesman Philip French on why Big Cup is so much better than any horrible Super League spin-off. HOW TO MAKE WAVES AND IRRITATE PEOPLE If you had just joined a major Premiership team for £3m, the first thing on your mind would be to win the fans over. Wouldn't you? "I never wanted to leave Tottenham," whined Aston Villa's David Ginola this morning in the caring sharing Daily Mail. "I was pushed out. Then all of a sudden this manager takes it all away from me." Holte End regulars may be forgiven for raising a plucked eyebrow at all this. But maybe they shouldn't take it as too big a slight on their club - because we reckon Gin has another agenda, like sticking it up the Tottenham manager, Arsenal's George Graham.
